Absolutely loved trying @secret.alchemist & it’s growing on me! They’re embracing mindful beauty; blending rare Indian botanicals with modern craftsmanship to create clean, conscious perfumery. Can’t wait to use these beauties!

Curating our calm in the dreamiest Washington escape. From waking up to serene lake views and blooming lotus pads, to cozy nights by the campfire, this @airbnb stay felt like the perfect balance of rustic charm and modern comfort. Every corner had thoughtful touches that made it feel extra wholesome. It was a space that truly felt like home away from home🏠

Slow mornings, skincare rituals, kayaking across still waters, and simply letting each moment sink in; this place made it so easy to pause and just be. Already wishing we could come back here with family and friends again!

Thanks for the memories @airbnb🥹

#AD #airbnbpartner
would you try the dusting powder hack?

Someone recently shared a very important point of view that made me see myself in a completely different light- which is to talk to my younger self whenever i feel unworthy, insecure or have self doubts. This month brought all of it.
When I started my channel in 2016, I was a girl full of fire, dreams & almost a desperation to feel a sense of accomplishment. I did not come from generational wealth, I didn't have any resources, contacts, investment money or someone to look up to who looked like me, talked like me, had a financial background like me. 
I will always remember this one time where i tried giving my room a 'pinteresty' look for a video & and was met by so much trolling for it being "low standard, cluttered or not cool enough" made me feel so small & helpless in a million ways. I still remember saving around ₹1500 and ordering 4 sheets of white brick wall stickers from amazon. It was the best 1.5k i had ever spent. 
Last year I won an award, hit 1 million subscribers, bought my dream house, built a safe space and yet i felt unworthy. Did i work for it or did i just get lucky? aah the self doubt rabbit hole.

So last night I tried talking to my younger self, the 2016 Aditi who made the most of every cloth fabric as her BG, who used a single eyeshadow palette to do her blush, contour, highlight & brows, who made shopping at sarojini nagar her whole identity because that is all she could afford, who somehow in her twisted brain thought that making videos will change her life. So I thanked her for doing exactly that- changing my life. Aditi, they were wrong, we made it, we have a roof over our heads now and mummy papa are proud, ravi is enjoying, everyone knows you, people respect your journey. You're surely going to go through a hell lot of things to get here that no one will ever know about. But i need you to let go of all the ghosts that haunt you or they will haunt you forever. Please set yourself free. 

So here's me letting go of the self doubt, cherishing my life, celebrating myself, taking my power back, doing what i do best- creating content, a reel that captures the essence of my side of the story 💕 because 2016 Aditi is proud of 2023 Quirky 🥹
he said ‘picture abhi baaki hai’ and booked Om Shanti Om tickets 🥹💖 #TinyDateTapes ep.2 👏🏼WELL PLAYED @ishankhanna58 🤛🏼

So here’s my at-home push + core workout: zero equipment, full burn 🔥

Workout flow after warmup: 
1️⃣ Push-Ups – 4 sets x 10 reps
2️⃣ Dive Bomber Push-Ups – 4 sets x 10 reps
3️⃣ Diamond Push-Ups – 4 sets x 10 reps
4️⃣ Plank to Push-Up – 2 sets x 10 reps

Core:
1️⃣ Crunches – 3 sets x 15 reps
2️⃣ Leg Raises – 3 sets x 12–15 reps
3️⃣ Plank Hold – 3 rounds x 40-60 seconds

Finished it off with a 30-min treadmill walk 
I’m not an expert and this is a beginner level workout that I do when I miss the gym :)

There’s something about a cool-toned caramel that just hits different and this one? She’s soft, radiant, and oh-so-dimensional. 🤎✨

The Iconic Browns Collection by @lorealpro_education_india is the hair color moment of the year and I finally gave in.
My Hair Pro at @geetanjalisalon by @israni.sumit nailed the brief and brought my dream shade to life with such finesse—it’s exactly what I envisioned❤️‍🔥

We went in with iNOA by L’Oréal Professionnel - a no-ammonia, oil-powered hair color that gave me this long-lasting glow without compromising scalp comfort. It feels light, luxurious, and totally me🥰

If you’re craving a refresh that’s subtle yet rich, trust me your perfect Iconic Brown is waiting💋

🫵 Share this with every Indian🇮🇳

Most people don’t know this, but the Government actually launched a Senior Citizen Card that costs only Rs.10 and gives huge benefits to elders across India.

From free hearing aids in Punjab, free doctor visits for bedridden seniors in Kerala, to free spectacles and walking sticks in Tamil Nadu, and flight (upto 25%) and train ( upto50%) ticket discounts — every state offers something valuable for our elders.

To apply, visit the official portal:
[https://services.india.gov.in/service/listing?ln=en&cat_id=44&sort=hit_count@desc]

Choose your state, then click on the Senior Citizen ID Card service link.
Fill the form, upload your age proof and address proof, pay just Rs.10, and submit.
Once verified, you’ll get your card digitally or by post, depending on your state’s process.

So if your grandparents or parents are above 60, help them apply today. It’s a small step that ensures they get the respect and facilities they truly deserve.

🫵🏻Aap kaunsa UPI App use karte ho?🤔

Now you can pay without entering your PIN.
Just use your fingerprint or face ID and it’s done.

And this is just the beginning.
Soon, ChatGPT will order groceries for you and make payments automatically.
NPCI, Razorpay, and OpenAI have introduced agentic payments using UPI Reserve Pay.
Money gets blocked first and is only deducted once your order is confirmed.
If the order is cancelled, the amount comes back instantly.

Right now, it’s being tested with BigBasket.
But in the future, it might come to Blinkit, Flipkart, and Amazon too.

And the craziest part, you’ll soon make payments through your smart glasses.
Meta Ray-Ban has already tested this.
Just say “Hey Meta, scan and pay 90 rupees” and the payment is done.

AI is not taking jobs, it’s making life smarter.
Follow TECH iELA for more future updates.

Here’s a roadmap to help you go from a software engineer to a data scientist 👩‍💻 👇

If you’re tired of writing vanilla apps and want to build ML systems instead, this one’s for you.

Step 1 – Learn Python and SQL (not Java, C++, or JavaScript).
→ Focus on pandas, numpy, scikit-learn, matplotlib
→ For SQL: use LeetCode or StrataScratch to practice real-world queries
→ Don’t just write code—learn to think in data

Step 2 – Build your foundation in statistics + math.
→ Start with Practical Statistics for Data Scientists
→ Learn: probability, hypothesis testing, confidence intervals, distributions
→ Brush up on linear algebra (vectors, dot products) and calculus (gradients, chain rule)

Step 3 – Learn ML the right way.
→ Do Andrew Ng’s ML course (Deeplearning.ai)
→ Master the full pipeline: cleaning → feature engineering → modeling → evaluation
→ Read Elements of Statistical Learning or Sutton & Barto if you want to go deeper

Step 4 – Build 2–3 real, messy projects.
→ Don’t follow toy tutorials
→ Use APIs or scrape data, build full pipelines, and deploy using Streamlit or Gradio
→ Upload everything to GitHub with a clear README

Step 5 – Become a storyteller with data.
→ Read Storytelling with Data by Cole Knaflic
→ Learn to explain your findings to non-technical teams
→ Practice communicating precision/recall/F1 in simple language

Step 6 – Stay current. Never stop learning.
→ Follow PapersWithCode (it's now sun-setted, use huggingface.co/papers/trending, ArXiv Sanity, and follow ML practitioners on LinkedIn

→ Join communities, follow researchers, and keep shipping new experiments

-------
Save this for later.
Tag a friend who’s trying to make the switch.

[software engineer to data scientist, ML career roadmap, python for data science, SQL for ML, statistics for ML, data science career guide, ML project ideas, data storytelling, becoming a data scientist, ML learning path 2025]

If I were to get started to learn LLMs — here’s exactly how I’d go about it 👇

(No degree, no prior experience needed. Just consistency and curiosity.)

Step 1: Learn Python (Weeks 1–4)
→ Do “Python for Everybody” or freeCodeCamp
→ Practice daily for 30 minutes
→ Push everything to GitHub — even your messy code
→ Start building your proof of work from Day 1

Step 2: Get ML Foundations (Weeks 5–8)
→ Take Andrew Ng’s ML course (still gold)
→ Pick 1 project on Kaggle (Titanic is great for starters)
→ Train a basic model → deploy it with Streamlit
→ Now you’ve built your first ML app 👏

Step 3: Deep Learning Phase (Months 3–4)
→ Learn through fast.ai — super hands-on
→ Fine-tune a small transformer (like BERT) on Hugging Face
→ Don’t aim for perfection, aim to finish one project well

Step 4: Understand Transformers & LLMs (Months 5–6)
→ Rebuild a mini GPT using Karpathy’s nanoGPT
→ This will help you actually understand self-attention, tokens, and training loops
→ Watch explainer videos + read blog posts to reinforce the concepts

Step 5: Learn the Real LLM Stack (Months 7–9)
→ LangChain for chaining prompts & calling tools
→ LangGraph for multi-agent workflows and memory
→ Weaviate or LanceDB for retrieval (RAG setups)
→ QLoRA for fine-tuning open models
→ vLLM for efficient inference

Step 6: Build and Publish (Months 10–12)
→ Choose one simple use case (like a research assistant or AI chatbot)
→ Build it end-to-end using the stack you’ve learned
→ Make a demo video, write a short architecture breakdown
→ Share on GitHub, LinkedIn, and Twitter — this is your new resume

Portfolio project ideas: https://www.instagram.com/p/DG6l_MrShZ8/?igsh=NTc4MTIwNjQ2YQ==

Comment ‘AI’ below and I’ll send you my First 3 Post Templates — the same ones I used when I started building my LinkedIn presence from scratch.

If you’ve ever stared at that “Start a post” box and thought, what do I even say? — you’re not alone.
Your first few posts don’t need to be perfect. They just need to be real. 

Talk about what you’re learning, what you’re building, or who inspired you this week.

That’s how you start showing up — not as a content creator, but as a professional with a story worth sharing.

If you’re an aspiring ML or AI engineer,
here are 5 projects you can build right now to get your hands dirty with the latest tools, and actually understand how things work end-to-end 👇🏽

🛠️ 1. Build an ML Pipeline from Scratch
Project: Predict which students are at risk of dropping out
→ Pull attendance + grades → clean in Pandas/Polars
→ Train with LightGBM → track with MLflow
→ Deploy via FastAPI + Docker → push to AWS Lambda
→ Set up CI/CD with GitHub Actions
💡 This is a full ML lifecycle in one project.

💬 2. Build a RAG Chatbot
Project: A chatbot that answers questions from course notes
→ Chunk + embed using LlamaIndex / Cohere / VoyageAI
→ Store in Weaviate or FAISS
→ Use an open-source LLM like Mistral or Qwen
→ UI in Gradio or Streamlit
💡 Great hands-on intro to how GenAI apps actually work.

🧠 3. Fine-Tune an LLM for a Domain
Project: A medical or finance assistant
→ Collect PubMed papers or SEC filings
→ Fine-tune with QLoRA/DPO
→ Start with Mistral or DeepSeek Coder
→ Evaluate on factuality + accuracy
→ Deploy with Modal or Fireworks AI
💡 Helps you go deeper into foundation model adaptation.

🚨 4. Monitor for Model Drift
Project: A fraud detection system that stays effective post-launch
→ Serve with BentoML
→ Track drift using Evidently AI or WhyLabs
→ Use Airflow/Prefect for retraining
→ Visualize everything in Grafana
💡 Most ML projects die post-deployment, this one shows you can maintain.

🍽️ 5. Build a Multimodal AI App
Project: Snap a photo of food → get nutrition + recipes
→ Use Florence-2 or CLIP for vision embeddings
→ Add Qwen-VL or LLaVA for reasoning
→ Build the UI with Streamlit
💡 You’ll learn how to mix modalities and push boundaries.

None of these are “easy,” but that’s the point.
They’ll teach you the actual workflow, data prep → modeling → deployment → monitoring.
And they’ll stand out when someone looks at your GitHub or portfolio.

If you end up building one of these (or already have), drop a link in the comments, I’d love to see it 🙌🏽

Comment ‘AI’ to join the Context Engineering for GenAI workshop

If you’re preparing for your next AI engineering interview,
there’s one concept you must be ready to explain: Context Engineering.

It’s how GenAI systems actually think.
Instead of prompting models blindly, you design what information the LLM sees, retrieves, and remembers — using RAG, summarization, query rewriting, and memory.

This is how real-world AI products move from output generation → intelligent reasoning.

We’re breaking it down step-by-step in the upcoming workshop.

Comment "AI" to get the LinkedIn Experience Template

Recruiters only scan 3 things in your experience section — and 99% of profiles miss all three.

They’re looking for:

1. What you did (your real contribution)

2. How it created impact (not just what tool you used)

3. What skills you demonstrated (the ones that actually matter for the next role)

Most people treat LinkedIn like a resume. But it’s not. It’s your highlight reel.

Don’t just list responsibilities — show results.
That’s what makes a recruiter stop scrolling.

[linkedin tips, career growth, professional branding, job search strategy, resume writing, recruiter tips, career storytelling, tech professionals, personal brand, linkedin strategy]

If I could go back to college, I’d tell myself this:

1. Don’t limit yourself to the syllabus. It’s the bare minimum.

2. Experiment as much as you can. It’s the safest time to fail.

3. Be intentional with your direction. Don’t just follow the crowd.

4. Build your network early. One conversation can change everything.

5. Create instead of just consuming. People can’t value what they can’t see.

College isn’t just about grades. It’s about building the foundation for who you want to become.

Switching from pads & tampons to period panties changed everything about how I bleed & I wish that for every menstruator- the comfort, awareness, even how I feel about my cycle -it’s so different than it was with tampons/pads. 

No stickiness, no dryness, no constant checking. Just soft, breathable fabric that I live in. I honestly forget I’m even bleeding. I prefer the modal ones over the cotton. They feel softer but cotton is more economical if you’re on a budget. Use my code for a 15% off ok- applicable only on panties and not packs 🫶🏻

Most disposable pads & tampons contain bleach, dioxins, & fragrance chemicals that are known to interfere with women’s hormones & contribute to disorders like PCOS, endometriosis, & fertility issues. It’s really sad but it’s true. I gave up on pads in 2016 & used tampons till 2023 - uff, the harm I’ve caused my body unknowingly, wish there was more awareness around the same as there is now. All those medicines, ultrasounds, pain, panic & irregular periods I went through because of my PCOS - I wish that upon no one. 

Rinse → machine wash → sun dry. That’s it. They last for years, so I haven’t bought pads or tampons in 2 whole years. I did experiment with a menstrual cup but I think it’s not particularly inclusive especially for women with vaginismus. It does the job but sometimes I do panic when I’m unable to get it out or put it back inside.. 😥Period panties that way, are every uterus friendly & stress free. 😅

I now bleed guilt free. No tampons and pads have gone to the landfill because of me in the last 24 months. 🎉🎉 Feels like an achievement to be honest!

Also, my flow feels more natural & I feel more in sync with my body - hard to explain but it just happens.
And well, about Mahina - there’s something safe about knowing you don’t need a product designed for convenience, you just need something designed with care & with an all women’s team, you don’t expect anything less! I love what they’ve done & i’m very grateful they exist.

I promise you will feel the same way. 🫶🏻

Lala Munshi Ram’s (my Daadu’s name was also Munshi Ram!!) journey began in Pakpattan, Pakistan, where their renowned confectionery shop, ‘Toshe,’ flourished. 

After the partition in 1947, they relocated to Fazilka, India, with their five sons, establishing ‘Tosha,’ in 1949, a new confectionery shop. Over the years, their dedication led to the shop’s success, earning it the moniker ‘Fazilka ka Tosha.’ 

Today, the third generation has rebranded it as “Pakpattaniyan di Hatti,” breathing new life into the legacy. Collaborating with Mandeep from United Foods, the fourth generation introduced enticing flavors and improved packaging, extending the shelf life to two months.

‘Tosha’ symbolizes love and unity, captivating customers with its exceptional taste and leaving them longing for more. 

the website is www.toshewala.in :)

For me, Tosha reminds me of my grandparents (all four) and all that they had to leave behind during the partition..homes, cattle, land, families…it’s utterly nostalgic, bittersweet, and satisfies in me the longing to get to know life on the other side. May never happen in this lifetime but this is the closest I’ll get :)

I’m sure most North Indians whose ancestors come from the other side of the border, feel that longing often too. 🌸 Let me know if you resonate :) Does your family also come from the other side of the border? 💕

#punjab #india #pakistan #tosha #fyp #foryou #love #gulabjamun #foodie #history

SAVE FOR LATER🌸 read⬇️

I saw Raan on Google Maps in a village called Are & looked at how far it was from Dapoli, where I was at the time. Only an hour-ish by road - so I immediately booked 6 nights & left for Guhagar :)

🌸 The place is the brainchild of a very cool 33 year old called Mohit who is an absolute nerd & will excitedly tell you more than you need to know about Guhagar, Maharashtra, the tribal culture, the food, the caste system, the women who work at the property, will also casually spot species of birds and butterflies in hopes you will remember.

🌸 An engineer by “profession”, he is someone who has worked & lived in France & Chile, & very naturally picked up Spanish & French as languages he still talks in. He also backpacked through South America in 2017 & learnt about sustainable living from the tribes & locals he met, which ended up changing the course of his life in incredibly profound ways. He came back to India knowing he certainly wants to do something in sustainable travel..what, he wasn’t sure of, but he knew he wanted to do his best in preserving the many cultures & traditions of Maharashtra, one tribal village at a time. Thus, began his little venture called Swadesee, a platform that connected urban people to rural Maharashtra. Unfortunately, it took a hit during the pandemic & hasn’t been operational since. However, the soul & intention of Swadesee was carefully transferred into Raan (which means wild in Marathi) & continues to linger in every decision he takes for the place. 

🌸 There are around 11 local women who run the entire place- from the reception, to housekeeping, to cooking in the kitchen. They’re well respected, well paid & love meeting new people from all over. 

🌸 Pets are not allowed because there’s so much wildlife around Raan that needs to be protected in the smallest ways possible.

🌸 Pre booking on their website is a must- no walk ins

🌸 Direct buses exist from Mumbai to Guhagar & the closest train station to Raan is Chiplun. 

🌸 their website has all info you’ll need before coming

🌸 NO ACs here!

🌸 if you’re a chill, soft, nature loving person, you will love love love @raanguhagar 

K bye, ENJOY ☺️🩷

HOME 🧡🤍💚

There was a time when travelling across India felt like falling in love again and again. Every journey had a heartbeat of its own, dhabba stops on mountain roads, laughter with strangers who became family, the chaos, the dust, the sunsets that made everything worth it. 
 But somewhere along the way, something changed. The way the government was functioning, the growing divide, the exhaustion - it all began to weigh on me. The very fabric of this country that once felt colourful and alive started to feel worn out. I think I slowly fell out of love with India, not because I stopped caring, but because watching her crumble in parts broke my heart.

So I began to look outward.
 Over the last few years, I’ve travelled to Bangladesh, Borneo, Turkey, Azerbaijan, Thailand, Vietnam, Mongolia, Sri Lanka, Germany etc. Each country taught me something about culture, about humanity, about myself. Some were chaotic and soulful, some calm and pristine. Yet, even in all that movement, something inside me always felt slightly untethered.

And then I went to Hampi.
 A single week there changed everything. The wild landscapes, the sunsets, the warmth of strangers, the quiet honesty of it all - it reminded me of the India I once knew. The one that makes you feel alive even when everything around you feels uncertain.

It’s strange.. I’ve seen so much of the world this year, yet it was one small corner of my own country that reminded me why I fell in love with travel in the first place.

I’m not abandoning the world - there’s still so much I want to explore.. but I’m coming home differently now. Not rerouting, just reconnecting.
Because for all her flaws and contradictions, India still holds everything I’ve ever been searching for - rawness, depth, humanity, truth. And maybe, in finding my way back to her, I’ll find my way back to myself too. 
🇮🇳✨

#india #love #travelinindia #fyp #foryou #homebound :)

READ before you judge⏬ 🐎 

🇲🇳 In Mongolia, horses are everything. They’re family, transport, strength, pride and sometimes, food.
It’s hard to understand that at first. Especially when you grow up seeing horses as sacred, wild, untouchable beings. But here, they’re not just symbols of beauty; they’re a way of life.

The Mongolian way of living is deeply intertwined with nature - not in a poetic, Instagram kind of way, but in a raw, matter-of-fact way. When winter lasts eight months and temperatures drop below -40°C, survival isn’t about choice, it’s about coexistence.

Everything in nature gives, and sometimes, everything is taken back.

You start to see that morality looks different when life depends on balance. That what feels right or wrong isn’t universal, it’s shaped by where you live, what the land gives, and what it demands in return.

Here, you don’t get to control nature; you adapt to it. You respect it. You thank it. And sometimes, that means accepting realities that make you uncomfortable.

In the end, you realise this truth that Mongolia teaches so quietly - life doesn’t always fit into right and wrong. Sometimes it just is what it is.

A quiet reminder that coexistence isn’t about comfort…it’s about understanding.

If you were here, would you eat horse me@t - or would you pass? Be honest. 🐎 

I personally didn’t and won’t try but I am taking the tooth as a souvenir of the Mongol spirit. 🌸

#mongolia #animals #horses #equistrian #asia #mongol #travel #foryou #fyp

I first booked a very random place in Hampi for the night and was left so disappointed. ☹️ Then, I remembered there is a Zostel somewhere around and immediately knew what to do- I put it on google maps, it was some 20 kms away! So I rented a scooty the next day, loaded my bag and left! Uff- BEST DECISION!🌸

✨The property has its own story - everyone in the climbing (boulders) community knows of Sharmila aunty and her three sons, from the Goan Corner, an old establishment in the Hampi Island that was demolished alongside 18 others in March 2020. While they were left homeless for 3 months, they knew they have to start again…bigger, better…which made them purchase this land, away from everything, and start afresh. What you see here is years of hard work, resilience and a zeal that brought the Goan Corner back to life and they continue to host thousands of people every year and keep them happy.

They also have a deep love for animals, gardening, sustainable architecture and it shows! There’s also bunnies, turtles, fish and monitor lizards!!🦎 

And yes they’re under the Zostel umbrella but the place is FULLY family run. It’s amazing to be around them, the way they treat their guests and help them, the way the staff takes care of you and the way the ANIMALSSSSS, alll of them, make sure to let you not be sad even for a second!! it’s amazing 🥰🥰🥰

If you ever find yourself planning a trip to Hampi, book Zostel Hampi to have the best time! 

🪐 I met such lovely souls from all over, spent time with them, swam in the pond, doodled, went on scooty rides, watched movies in the dining hall and spent SO MUCH TIME IN THE LAP OF NATURE 🍃🌱

📅 Hampi’s season time is September to February and post that; it’s toooo hot to do anything! So plan a trip soon 🫶🏻 

Have a beautiful trip- don’t be obsessed with sightseeing. Take everyday as it comes, in Hampi🧡

PS. If you don’t like animals, then don’t go here. Don’t expect them to accommodate their pets as per your liking.

🌦️Monsoon in Goa >>>> 

warning ⚠️ please look out for snakes, leeches and cops if you go & do not jump into quarries if you don’t see anyone around. many a people have lost their lives over the last few years & that’s why there’s usually restrictions at their entryways. please stay safe. 

what you see here is called a quarry, which is essentially a scar left behind by the mining industry in goa. back in the day when Goa was ruled by the Portuguese, some 800 mines were set up all over the state for manganese, iron, laterite and red soil. along the way, traditional societies collapsed. Migration into Goa was heavy. handling of machinery- trucks, barges was the domain of men. Women lost status, from being equals in the fields, they were progressively non-earning. as scale increased, the damage multiplied. fields became less and less productive. smoke was spewed by trucks while iron ore dust blew off trucks and barges. khazan bunds were damaged in the process and so much more…leading to a collapse of another long lived society.

things finally changed once Goa became liberated from the Portuguese in 1961 and in 1987, after a number of previous efforts, the Indian government abolished mining altogether. it wasn’t a profitable industry, was the cause of mass ecological destruction and its impact on the Goan society was deeply problematic. by 2007, after a lot of malpractices, PILs, Supreme Court hearings, mining in goa eventually became illegal. 

these abandoned quarries that become natural pools/reservoirs of rainwater are a symbol of all that was lost and all that was saved. every monsoon, locals and migrants alike, spend time at these quarries, away from the quiet to enjoy the rare sunny days in the four month long monsoon that heralds goa every year. ✨

the current government has thrown all the efforts away, of people who finally made it possible for goa to be mining free, and restarted mining in a very hushed manner, by renewing leases to the same miners.

things are changing rapidly, & its very unsettling to be in the midst of it, knowing very well the damage today’s decisions will cause.

as for today & this day, all i am and can be, is grateful. 🌸

#goa

🇩🇪 PUBLIC UNIVERSITIES >>> 

✨ I used to believe studying abroad is expensive but my recent trip to Bamberg changed everything. It is actually affordable- I I was just looking at the wrong options!🙈 Public universities in Germany are utterly economical & have an impeccable standard of education. Most charge no tuition fees at all, just a small semester fee while private universities can burn a hole of €10,000–€20,000 a year in your pocket! That’s money you could spend on travel, a good rental accommodation, experiences, food, and actually living your life.

✨Take the University of Bamberg. The fee for most courses even for international students is around 120€ per semester!! 😳 I was so shocked when I heard about it for the first time- like seriously? That’s it? It’s a cosy, student-friendly public uni with 5 campuses spread across Bamberg and you can choose from programmes like International Software Systems Science, Strategy & Sustainability, English and American Studies, and even dual degrees in Political Science and Sociology. Most Indians here are seen taking up Computer Sciences 😝 

✨There are courses in English, but if you know German, your options (& your everyday life) open up massively.

✨Ohhh also, learning German before you arrive is the smartest investment you’ll make. It means house-hunting without stress, breezing through bureaucratic paperwork, ordering your coffee without pointing at the menu, and finding part-time work more easily. A few months of language classes cost way less than a single semester at a private university and the payoff is priceless. Check out @german_with_amit 📖📚

✨Also you won’t be alone - the Indian community in Germany is thriving, now over 300,000 strong. You’ll find friendly faces, cultural events, and a network that makes this new chapter feel a little like home.

What I’ve learnt? Pick a public university like Bamberg, learn some German, save for a year, arrive not just debt-free, but ready to live a good life in Germany. 🤓

I’m SERIOUSLY considering!! It would be a really cool thing to do for my own self. 🌿

⤵️ SAVE FOR LATER 🌿🇬🇪

We loved Georgia so much we are going to go here again ❤️🇬🇪

🚙 We rented a Toyota Rav4 from this website called localrent.com after checking quite a few pricy websites and completely giving up on our road trip plan. The car cost us 400$/ 34,000₹ for 9 days with full insurance, no deposit. Divided between two, it was only 200$/ 17,155₹ each. 

🪪 An IDP (International Driving Permit) was required so I suggest logging on to www.internationaldriversassociation.com and getting one for yourself (get the 3 year one- higher value). That costs around ₹8000 with hard copy + courier. 

🤑 Our car rental gave us a code to use at the Wissol Petrol pumps which gave us a 15% off on Premium petrol and the mileage of the car was superb. Overall, we spent around ₹12,000 on fuel. 

✈️ Our flights from Delhi to Tbilisi cost approx ₹18,000 each. And, our outbound flight from Kutaisi to Frankfurt cost approx ₹17,000 each. 

🏨 Accomodation mostly always cost us anywhere between ₹900-₹1800 each. Hostels, guest houses, home stays and hotels included. 

🍛 The food always cost us anywhere between ₹250-1500 per person depending on the place. 

🇺🇸 We didn’t need to apply for a visa separately as we each have a US visa. 

💰 According to our Splitwise, we ended up spending around ₹1,80,000 for 13 days including stay, food, flights, car rental, miscellaneous purchases, fuel, entry fees to places, wine etc! 

🥹 1000% returning for a second road trip. Autumn, it’ll loooook unimaginably beautiful!!🍁🍂

Places we recommend: 

✨ 3-4 days in Tbilisi Old Town
✨ 3-4 days in and around Kazbegi (Dariali, Sno, Juta)
✨ 3-4 days in Racha (or Svaneti) 
✨2 days in the Martvili region (can totally avoid the Martvili Canyon and opt for local waterfalls instead) 
✨ 3 days in Batumi + Kutaisi 

⏱️Best time to visit Georgia: CAN I HIGHLY SUGGEST AUTUMN?? 🍂 Omg, if you’re planning your Georgia trip, let it be in October. Everything will be orange, red, auburn!

Share this with someone you want to go to Georgia withhhh❤️❤️❤️

We grew up in the noise.
The kind that wasn’t just outside- traffic, horns, generators during power cuts.
It was inside too.
Tuition at 5. Homework by 7. Eat fast. Sleep early.
Be better. Be quiet. Be grateful.
Become an engineer, a doctor. Or don’t come home with dreams. 

Our cities were in-between.
Saharanpur and Jabalpur.
Not quite big enough to offer options.
Not small enough to offer silence.
So we lived in cement houses with tiled floors and repressed feelings,
where “what will people say” echoed louder than our own voices.

We didn’t have forests.
We didn’t talk about therapy.
We talked about marks, medals, and that neighbour’s kid who cracked IIT.
Home wasn’t always safe.
Sometimes, it was a battleground of unhealed adults and scared children playing the role of a happy family.

And yet,
somewhere in that mess, we held onto wonder.
I came to Goa two years ago, thinking I was just moving.
I didn’t know I was going to unlearn how to rush through life.
I didn’t know silence would feel like a balm.
I didn’t know mornings could begin with birdsong and not dread.
That there was something sacred in soft rains, in sitting on the floor to eat,
in conversations that didn’t need fixing…just presence.
The slowness rewired our nervous systems. 
The coconut trees and the sea listened better than people ever did.

Now, the silence feels addictive.
The calm isn’t a luxury, it’s medicine.
And for the first time in a long time,
We are not surviving.
We are simply…here. Alive. Healing. Becoming.

Big thanks to the mountains of Georgia for letting us be, to allowing us to dwell in the silence, to feel, to smile and simply exist. This will not be our last visit. ❤️✨

What helped you start healing? Tell in the comments✨

SAVE THIS REEL FOR YOUR 🇬🇪 TRIP!🫶🏻✨

If you only visit one market in Tbilisi, let it be this one. Not for the souvenirs, but for the stories.
A market of memories - yes, that’s what it is. Laid out under the Georgian sun, come summer, spring, autumn or even sometimes in winter, the Dry Bridge Flea Market has been around since before I was born! 

From Soviet medals to hand-painted ceramics, this Market in Tbilisi is a living archive of stories. I had randomly marked it on my Maps and wasn’t sure if I’ll end up visiting. However, the weather was beautiful and it was day 3 in Tbilisi when I decided to walk 27 minutes from Old Town to the bridge and see what the market looks like. I had zero expectations but I left feeling pleased with myself for coming here. 

✨ This place may not be everyone’s cup of tea. It’s not posh, not touristy. Not everyone likes to or has the patience to sort through each and every stall to look for a piece they’ll end up picking up. Hence, I’ve mentioned, it’s specifically for collectors. Collectors of weird items and old, of cutlery and home decor pieces, old cameras (working and non working), silver and brass antiques- you’re essentially invited to have a peek into someone’s personal collection and pay for a piece if you like.

✨ Please don’t bargain like your life depends on it. Not here. Eventually, they’ll simply start getting angrier with tourists if you behave improperly so just don’t be irritating. People price things very decently, at least presently. Maximum you can try and bargain by a few Laris if you’re picking up more than a piece but please don’t insist too hard. You’ll understand better once you visit why I’m saying so. 🫶🏻

✨ You’ll definitely end up spending a few hours here so come prepared. 

📍 Dry Bridge Flea Market, Tbilisi
🕰 Open daily, 11 am (or 12 pm, Georgia wakes up slowly) to 5 pm (weather dependent)
💸 Bring cash 

Hope you end up visiting- tell me if you do!❤️❤️ 

Love

Are you an accidental hoarder too?🙈🙉🙊

I thought I was just cleaning my cupboard.
But halfway through, sitting with a mountain of old clothes and memories, I realised I was actually sitting with myself.

Each piece had a story. A phase. A version of me I had not met in a while. Some still felt like home. Others felt like someone I used to know.

It made me pause. I have been holding on. To things I no longer wear, habits I no longer need, and identities I have quietly outgrown.

I used to think I needed more. More space, more options, more stuff, just in case.
But maybe what I have been craving is not more. Maybe it is less, with intention. Less clutter, more clarity. Less noise, more truth.

This little act of folding, sorting, giving away
felt like a kind of homecoming. A reminder that growth is not always loud or dramatic. Sometimes, it is soft. Messy. Quietly brave.

I’m learning, how minimalism is not about getting rid of everything.
It is about choosing, gently, what stays close to you.
And knowing when to let go, with love.

If this stirred something in you, I hope you use it as a sign to bring some sanity back into your life or.. send it to someone who could use a day of decluttering cuz it genuinely works out so well. 🫶🏻✨

Let me know what you thought while watching the video. Always love to hear. 🥰

Made for my neurodivergent mind, but honestly helpful for anyone who feels a little all over the place.

Okay bye, Imma go romanticise my to-do list now and report back to tell you how I’m doing 🐣

So yeah in case you’d like the same for yourself, comment “plan” to get a pdf of the same 💚🍢 and may you all get a friend like @ria.mohta 🥰😭❤️‍🩹

guess what flat bellies can’t do? this 🤓😌

it’s been a long long journey :)

still continues to be..but at least now i don’t compare myself with others, at least now i don’t feel ashamed of being ‘fat’, at least now i don’t carry the weight of being 80 kgs +, at least now i don’t look at my body as an excuse for not being able to do things others can.

whatever happens now, whether i loose this weight or not..it doesn’t matter. i’ve now understood that its our inner peace and health that must always be a priority. 

and for the first time, i feel free in my body..
because it’s mine.
because it carries me.
because it’s alive.
because it has held me through pain, joy, change, and healing.
because it lets me move, feel, rest, love.
because it doesn’t need to look like anyone else’s to be worthy.
because it deserves kindness, not criticism.
because it’s done nothing but show up for me, every single day.

and maybe that’s what love really is
not perfection, not control, not shrinking yourself to fit in.
but showing up for yourself, in soft ways.
being patient on the hard days.
forgiving the mirror when it feels heavy.
choosing nourishment over punishment.
choosing softness over shame.
choosing to stay, even when it’s easier to disconnect.

i don’t know what the future holds for my body.
but i know now:
it is not my enemy.
it’s not something to fix.
it’s the place i live in.
the only home i’ve ever had.

and finally, finally,
i’ve started to treat it like one.

and that, in itself, is everything.

cheers to us ✨🦦

I was so lost..
so angry,
so sad all the time. 

I was on an emotional roller coaster
all day,
everyday. 

Something had to change,
Most things had to be unlearnt.

The negative self talk, 
the constant self sabotage,
the habit of seeking perfectionism,
the need for validation, 
the need to be needed,
the needed for constant external reassurance.

I was so far away from myself, from my core, from my inner child. I knew I couldn’t go on like this. So, in February, I registered for a 200 hour Yoga Teacher Training Course which not only strengthens your knowledge of Yoga, but also allows you to teach it someday, to others, if you’d want to (most people opt for other courses and specialisations after this beginner course, if they really want to be a proper teacher). I was so skeptical at first..oh I don’t know if I can, oh but what if this, what if that…all sorts of excuses came bubbling up to the surface. After postponing it once, I was going to postpone it again. But this time, I stood my ground and faced this big 24 day commitment that I’d paid the advance for. 9/24 days have passed and I feel like I’ve been here since forever.

I love love love my routine, my batchmates, our teachers, I love all that I’m getting to learn about the body, the mind and the soul. We have classes all day from 5:30 am to 7:30 pm. We start with Pranayama and end the day with Meditation. The types of Yoga we have include Vinyasa, Hatha, Yin, Aerial, Ashtanga and SUP. Then in theory, we study Teaching Methodology, Posture corrections, Yoga Anatomy and a lot more. 

I’m in school and no one’s forcing me to be here- I’m here with all my heart and soul. There are shifts happening all across my nervous system, i’m unlearning so much, i’m coming face to face with so many fears and honestly, I needed this for myself.

I needed this so badly. 

In two weeks, I’ll graduate from here. I have to give a written exam and a practical one but my current focus is more on getting to hold on to my headstand by the end of it. 🤣

I don’t know if I will be a teacher someday but I do know I am here to be better and live better.

And for now, that’s all that matters. ✨

#yoga #yogattc #ttc #yogaindia #india

I spent 6 days in the magical country of Kenya and here’s my itinerary! 🇰🇪🦓🦒🌿

💻 HOW TO BOOK: I booked the tour through @james_munyiri_safari and can’t recommend him enough (reach out to him if you want to plan a trip to Kenya, Whatsapp: +254 722225107)!

DAY 1: Nairobi to Maasai Mara
🚗 Picked up from the airport, we headed south to Maasai Mara, with a stop at the breathtaking Great Rift Valley. Checked into KEEKOROK LODGE, and dived straight into an evening game drive. Witnessed the sun setting over the Mara and spent over an hour with a LEOPARD - an unforgettable start! 🌅🐆

DAYS 2/3: Full Day Maasai Mara Safari
🌞 Early mornings and thrilling game drives - two full days of spotting so many animals - countless lions, zebras, elephants, cape buffalo, giraffes, wildebeest, and cheetah. We went up to The Mara River (great to see the Great Migration but we weren’t lucky the day we visited), and the Keekorok Lodge became our home, offering warm dinners and cozy overnights after exhilarating days in the wild. 🦁🦓

DAY 4: Masai Mara to Lake Nakuru
🎈 A sunrise Balloon Safari, visiting a Masai Village and a journey to Lake Nakuru - the LAKE NAKURU LODGE awaited us. Lunch on the way, and we were mesmerized by the wonders of Lake Nakuru National Park! Flamingoes, diverse birdlife, and a comfortable night’s rest in the jungle. 🦩🦓

DAY 5: Lake Nakuru 
🌅 An early morning game drive at Lake Nakuru where we spotted tons of rhinos (Big 5 done in Kenya!) followed by a scenic drive to Naivasha. Enjoyed a Boat Ride in Lake Naivasha and spotted hippos and pelicans in the water. Then settled into the serene SAWELA LODGES. 🚤🦩

DAY 6: Naivasha to Nairobi
🚙 Had a laid-back morning in Naivasha and drove down to Nairobi. Tried some Ethiopian food for lunch and headed to the Giraffe Center where we got to feed some giraffes, which was such a cool experience! 🦒

If you have more time, you can also visit Amboseli National Park and maybe do a trip to Zanzibar (both things I wish I’d done).

You can customize your tour with @james_munyiri_safari.

I traveled to Budapest to take a public bath—worth it! ✨

Széchenyi Thermal Bath is an absolute must-visit, with 18 pools, stunning Art Nouveau vibes, and mineral-rich waters straight from natural hot springs. This is the largest medicinal bath in Europe; from steaming outdoor pools to saunas and salt chambers, it’s the perfect spot to soak, sweat, and chill. 🛁

Pro tip: Book online to skip the line and enjoy a seamless experience with a private cabin for your stuff (I paid 32 euros for the private cabin but I think the price has gone up to 39 euros now). Whether solo or with friends, this iconic bathhouse is relaxation at its finest. And besides this, there are tons of other thermal baths in the city worth checking out too!

Who’s adding this to their Budapest bucket list? 🏰🫧

Malta surprised me! It’s tiny, but getting around still takes time! Buses are affordable but slow, so ferries and cabs save you time if you’re short on days. Most major spots like Valletta, Birgu, and Mdina are within 30–45 minutes of each other. 🚖⛴️

Also, Gozo is way more relaxed than the main island — you can explore it in a day but I recommend spending a night there like I did to really get a feel of the island. 🏝️ 

And yes, you can easily do a beautiful, full sightseeing day under €150 if you plan well (I wasn’t trying to be on a budget as such and since I was switching islands, I ended up spending a bit more than I would have). 💰

Would you call this expensive or pretty fair for a full day in Malta? 🤔

I spent 5 days in Malta, and honestly, it felt just right — enough time to explore Valletta, Mdina, Gozo, the Three Cities, and the Blue Grotto without rushing. 🌊

I absolutely love Italy and Croatia (and hope to visit Greece soon!), so this isn’t to discourage anyone from going there. Malta just surprised me in the best way. And even though it’s quite popular among Europeans, I hardly see any Indians visiting it.

✈️ How to get there: Flights from India can be surprisingly affordable if you book in advance — mine was just 27,000 rupees one-way from Bangalore (Qatar Airways). There are also daily flights from most European hubs.

🏨 Where to stay: I stayed in Sliema and one night in Victoria, Gozo.
✨ Sliema: perfect for cafés and sunset strolls along the promenade.
✨ Valletta: ideal for history, museums, and charming streets.
✨ St. Julian’s: best for nightlife, restaurants, and the island’s liveliest vibes.
Getting around is easy!

🚖 How to get around: Ferries and cabs are affordable. Buses are well connected, though a bit slower. Renting a car gives you freedom to explore at your own pace.

🇲🇹 The ultimate 5-day Malta itinerary 🇲🇹👇🏻

If you’ve been dreaming of a Mediterranean escape with history, blue waters, and laid-back island charm, Malta needs to be on your list! 🏝️

Here’s my 5 day itinerary for Malta:

Day 1 – Valletta: Start in the capital city! Walk through centuries-old limestone streets, do a walking tour, visit St. John’s Co-Cathedral, Upper and Lower Barrakka Gardens, and the Grand Harbour. Stay for sunset drinks by the waterfront. Try a 7 course tasting menu at a Michelin guide restaurant - Legligin (it’s vegetarian friendly).

Day 2 – Gozo: Take the ferry to Gozo Island which is smaller, greener, and quieter. I did a hop-on-hop-off bus tour to explore Dwejra Bay & Blue Grotto, Ta Pinu, Ġgantija Temples, Ramla Bay, and the coastline. Spent the night in Victoria.

Day 3 – Back to Malta: Start your morning exploring the Citadel in Victoria. You can visit Comino Island (Blue Lagoon) for a swim or head back to Malta and visit The Three Cities (Vittoriosa, Senglea & Cospicua) — full of fortifications, cafes, and charm.

Day 4 – Mdina & Rabat: Step into a medieval movie set (Game of Thrones was shot here). Mdina’s narrow alleys and golden glow are magical at sunset. Rabat nearby is great for local food and history lovers. Have some cake and tea at Fontanella Tea Room with a stunning view.

Day 5 – South Malta: Explore the stunning Blue Grotto, the colourful Marsaxlokk fishing village (go on a Sunday for the market!), and Malta’s ancient temples like Ħaġar Qim & Mnajdra that are older than the pyramids!

💡 Things to know if you’re planning a trip to Malta:
	🛂 Visa: Malta is part of the Schengen Zone, so if you already have a Schengen visa, you’re good to go.
	💶 Currency: Euro (€)
	☀️ Best time to visit: April–June or September–October with warm weather, clear water, and fewer tourists.

Travel partner for this trip: @gtholidays.in 💛

Postcards from Malta 🇲🇹🫶🏻

Spent a week exploring Malta and it has really blown me away with everything it has to offer. From ancient fortresses to turquoise bays, Malta packs in more history and beauty than you’d expect from such a tiny island. 🏝️

One moment you’re wandering UNESCO-listed Valletta, the next you’re cliffside in Gozo or exploring some of the oldest manmade structures in the world (older than the pyramids). It’s the perfect mix of culture, coastlines, and Mediterranean charm, all in one trip 🌊🏛️🩵

8 places that I still can’t believe exist in Tasmania - the landscapes out here are insane! ✨

📍Freycinet National Park (2.5 hours from Hobart CBD)
My favourites were the Mt Amos hike (we did a sunrise hike) and Honeymoon Bay for sunset! 🥾

📍Maria Island (1 hour from Hobart CBD)
The best place in the state to see free roaming wombats! A walk to the Painted Cliffs at low tide is also a must! ⛴️

📍Eddystone Point Lighthouse (2.5 hours from Launceston CBD)
The best spot to see the red lichen covered rocks that make the Bay of Fires so special + there’s a lighthouse here too!🔥

📍Bruny Island (30 minutes from Hobart CBD)
We did this as a day trip, took the ferry over, saw white wallabies, went to the iconic Bruny Baker’s Bread Fridge and did the Bruny Island cruise! 🌊

📍Little Blue Lake (2 hours from Launceston CBD)
Originally a mine hole, the lake reflects a vivid aqua blue from the minerals in its base and there’s lots of vantage points to view it! 💙

📍Mt Paris Dam (1.5 hours from Launceston CBD) 
The structure was created by hand for the local mining industry, and in 1985, a hole was blasted in the wall to allow the flow of the Cascade River - now it’s such a magical scene! ✨

📍Trowutta Arch (3 hours from Launceston CBD) 
A short 1km return trail takes you through a beautiful rainforest-like setting to a magical arch way and still algae-covered cenote! 🌿

📍Cradle Mountain National Park (2.5 hours from Launceston CBD) 
Check out Ronny Creek to see wombats, do the Dove Lake Circuit or head up to Hansons Peak or Marions Lookout! 👀

How many of these have you been to or still need to get visit? ☺️

Just 2 hours from Melbourne, this one is a must see!✨

Steavenson Falls is probably my favourite waterfall in Victoria, even after visiting almost 80 of them across the state - it’s floodlit everyday until 11pm at night and creates a truly magical and unique experience you can’t have anywhere else in Victoria! 🔦

Flowing all year round and accessible via a short 700 metre return walk from the car park (perfect for wheelchairs and prams) this waterfall has 4 different vantage points for viewing including a platform on either side, a bridge in front at a distance downstream and a platform at the top which can be accessed by a 800 metre walk uphill. 🥾

The best things about viewing at night are - no crowds, you can actually get a carpark, a different perspective of the falls and you avoid the heat of the day (especially in summer!) 🙌🏻

Who knew you could find this 2 hours from Melbourne!? 🌋

Mount Elephant is a steep sides scoria cone formed by a dormant volcano 20,000 years ago and rises 380 metres above sea level! 😮

You can hike 20 minutes to the crater from the visitor centre and do the 1 hour crater rim walk (approx. 4km altogether) if you’re feeling up to it (the views are amazing but it gets windy up there)! 💨

Keep your eye out for sheep grazing in the crater and hawks and eagles overhead 🐑

👉🏼 Keep in mind - Mt Elephant & Visitor Centre are open 1pm - 4pm on Sundays or by appointment but the site can be accessed on foot from the front gate at other times.

If you could go back in time to 2010... and invest your money in China, USA or India... in which country would you have made the most amount of money in?

Imagine you invested in the stock market index of each of these countries back in 2010...

If you were invested in the US, you would 6X your money in the past 15 years... which is almost 12.5% p.a.

Had you invested the same money in the Sensex, you would have 5X your money... which is around 11% p.a.

And had you invested in the Chinese index in Shanghai, you would have just 1.3X your money or made less than 2% p.a.

But why is it that China has boomed so much over the past two decades, but their stock market has almost remained flat since 2010.

Even right now, the PE multiple for the US is above 26X, for India is above 22X, and for China is just at 14X...

Which means investors don’t believe in its growth story compared to that of India and the US.

This is because of 3 main reasons:

1/ Almost half of the stocks listed on the Shanghai Composite are State Owned Enterprises (SOEs), similar to what we call PSUs in India, or Govt Owned Entities

And while the Private Players deliver 2X the Return on Equity compared to the SOEs, the latter keep the overall performance of the index down.

This brings us to the second reason, which is - Are Chinese SOEs not productive?

2/ Now the biggest paradox is that China’s GDP growth rate has no correlation to the stock market return - because while India and the US economy are highly dependent on the population buying and consuming products...

China’s GDP growth has come on the back of massive government spending, which is not always profit conscious...

So anyone who has invested in the Chinese index has had half of their money go into long term infra projects which are not the best for shareholder returns.

3/ And here comes the third reason - that despite China’s high spend on infrastructure growth, why are investors still giving it such a low PE and not betting on its future...

Because the Chinese government is unpredictable.

#casarthakahuja

The most beautiful country in the world is in a crisis... and it has come up as an opportunity for a number of Indians...

New Zealand is seeing one of the largest exits of its population...

Almost 20% of the citizens of New Zealand have left in recent years... with the highest number of over 120,000, making up almost 2.5% of the population leaving in 2024 alone.

But why are people leaving, and how are Indians using this?

People are leaving because housing prices are unaffordable, and the Kiwis find better job offers in Australia, which is an open economy to NZ citizens.

At this time, in 2024 alone, NZ has seen the largest inflow of Indians... over 27,000... and in June 2025, NZ has started recognising Indian degrees, not requiring Indians to pass additional exams in their country to fill in the shortage of labour... which is at a 50 year high!

There are 5 major types of skills which have been Green Listed that immediate residency visas are being given for:

1/ Healthcare Workers, i.e. Doctors, Nurses, Medical Lab professionals

2/ Engineers in Construction, Civil, and Construction Product Managers

3/ Software Engineers, Database Managers

4/ Environmental and other scientists

5/ Primary and Secondary Teachers

Even accountants and trade specialists are in demand.

For this visa, people need to give a letter of full time employment from a NZ employer along with proofs of skill and experience.

And most people who go to NZ use it as a backdoor entry to Australia legally...

By working in NZ for 5 years on residency, people apply for and get citizenship...

Once they get citizenship, they become eligible to work in Australia... so they go across to Australia in search for better pay, and then in 4 years of working in Australia... apply for Australian citizenship.

And one pattern I’m seeing emerge across the world is a huge demand for nurses - across Germany, Italy, Japan, Australia and New Zealand.

Populations are growing older... and they need skilled people from younger economies, paying them 3X the salary they get in India... nurses and healthcare professionals being the most in demand from India.

#casarthakahuja

Every person should have one folder in their computer that is the "In Case of Death" folder... and this is how it is structured...

The folder is used to manage and pass on one's assets to successors easily... and to avoid any legal hassles.

This folder is divided into 5 parts:

1/ Personal IDs
- Birth Certificate
- Marriage Certificate
- Aadhaar and Passport
- Divorce Decrees
- Change of Name Affidavits

2/ Legal & Estate Management Documents
- Last Registered Will with notarized copy
- Succession Certificates for Movable Assets
- Guardianship Documents for minor children / dependants

3/ Financial Assets and Accounts
- Bank Account details and statements
- Demat Account, Shares, Mutual Funds, Investment Portfolio
- Insurance Policy Documents with Beneficiaries
- Outstanding loan documents
- Bank Locker or Safe Deposit Locations and Access details

4/ Property Documentation - Real Estate and Business
- Property Deeds and Titles for Real Estate
- Mortgage Documents
- Rental Agreements
- Business Ownership Documents and Succession Plan

5/ Digital Assets and Access Information
- Email with recovery information
- Social media contact and legacy contact preferences
- Domain names, Cloud Storage
- Digital Subscriptions of material value

The best way to manage passwords here is to provide access to Password Managers where you can add an Emergency Contact who can access all passwords in case of such conditions. There are apps like 1Password, NordPass and Keeper which offer printable PDF documents for emergency access that can be kept in this folder.

These apps allow a waiting period from last activity after which the emergency contacts can use the data.

Also, please ensure that you submit all such documents for probate and get them drafted by a trusted lawyer.

I would also hope you would tell trusted family members about where you have stored this information so that they can access it when required.

Above all, wish you all a long and healthy life.

#casarthakahuja

Do you know what is the difference between the people of China, USA, Russia, India and the Middle East?

China is run by Engineers, US by Lawyers, Russia by the Security Forces, India by Generalist Bureaucrats, and the Middle East by Royal Technocrats...

👉🏻 China’s politicians used to be mostly from an Engineering background, which is why the country has historically taken economic decisions based on optimization... building structures to solve problems mathematically... 

which is why apart from economic growth, they also built math into social problems like the “One Child Policy”, and “Zero Covid Policy”, which backfired.

So while doing business with China, you should follow the hierarchy strictly, and talk more about science and efficiency than creativity and art.

👉🏻 Most members of the US Congress and most of the earlier US Presidents have been Lawyers... so the country has historically been run by judicial rights, procedural reviews, lots and lots of arguments... and is now moving towards being run by Businessmen.

So while dealing with Americans, be absolutely certain of the paperwork because they could sue you.

👉🏻 India has been run by the Bureaucrats that form the IAS... who are selected on a test that covers general knowledge more than technical skills...

And because highly virtuous and hardworking IAS officers could often go against political will and be transferred...

Thus, the country is run more by who you know than meritocracy.

👉🏻 Russia on the other hand is run by a President who has been part of the Security Forces for decades...

And thus the country prioritises national security over economic decisions...

And thus, as a foreigner doing business with Russia, you could be under surveillance as a foreigner, so always go as a friend, and be prepared to have opacity in decision making and not getting a reason for why it’s a yes or no.

👉🏻 The Middle East is run by Kings and Monarchs who are extremely innovation driven with a long term vision... which is why you see they’ve transformed the desert into the most desirable place in the world...

#casarthakahuja

Gold and Oil could lose their value for countries in the future, and the world economy is now revolving around another element...

I’m talking about Rare Earths... and let me explain what they are... and why they are shaping geopolitical relations...

There are 17 rare earth elements in the world, which are the most essential ingredient of every EV, every smartphone, every speaker and every defence equipment and fighter jet you see...

Neodymium is the most used today as it is used to make permanent magnets that are part of all these equipments... And the rarest of them all is terbium, which is extremely rare.

Quite like oil shaped the world economy for the past century...

The next economy is being built around rare earths... but their concentration of supply is even more pronounced than that of oil.

China has almost 37% of the world’s reserves... Brazil has 18%... and India has 6%...

Where India holds more reserves than USA, Russia, Australia, Canada, Vietnam, and all other countries in the world...

Such that just these 3 countries of China, Brazil and Russia have 60% of the world’s reserves...

But having reserves is not enough... Mining and Refining them is the real challenge... and China recognised this 30 years ago when in the 1990s it started tapping into its rare earth reserves such that it controls 90% of the rare earths today.

And this is also the reason why the US China tariff issue has been resolved even before the US India tariff issues can because China can stop all the supplies for any electronic or defence equipment that could be used by the US by just curtailing supply of rare earths to any country.

Mining and Refining them is extremely polluting to the world, and the reason Western countries have not done it is to meet their carbon emission goals.

Now, Oil has its substitutes in renewables, and Gold is just a store of value in uncertain times...

But its Rare Earths that don’t have substitutes as of now... and the world needs them such that the demand is going to be almost 6 times over the next 20 years... with price appreciation expected to be between 12-18% p.a. by 2040.

#casarthakahuja

The idea of this exercise is only to educate you on how a Fundamental Analysis using Trading Comparables method should be done to evaluate whether the valuation for a business makes sense.

I’ve done this by comparing Lenskart’s numbers and figures from Q1 FY 2025-26 (i.e. April to June 2025) across listed startups and traditional retail players.

By these numbers, the valuation may seemed to have been reasonable for all the institutional investors who are putting in money in the company.

Though, I must clarify that I don’t invest in IPOs, and this in no way is any recommendation for you to invest or not invest. This is only to educate on the method you should follow.

Please also add other ratios in your analysis that take into account balance sheet figures, and look at things like Return on Capital, Return on Assets, along a lot more, like Payback Period of Capex, etc.

I have pulled out data from several sources on the internet, adjusted and annualized to Q1 of FY26, so a few numbers may have changed when you look at current date figures.

I could have also made mistakes, and made a few reasonable assumptions in the data - but use sources like Screener, Perplexity, Capital IQ, and published reports of these companies to see for yourself.

Also, this video is much longer than the 3 minute limitation on Reels, so I know it won’t work as well as my other videos, but to crunch this in less than 3 minutes may grab headlines but not deliver true value.

#casarthakahuja

A big problem with buying an EV car is that its resale value is horrible...

This is because: 

👉🏼 The EV battery is easily 30-40% the cost of the total car...

And people have very little trust in what the condition of the battery is when they’re buying something in the used car market.

As there is no true battery health meter, and every manufacturer uses their own software, there is currently no standard measure to independently evaluate the health of an EV battery.

👉🏼 With the tech advancement in EVs, the range that you get in a new EV two years later is much higher than that in an old EV, so because of faster obsolescence, it makes sense to buy a new car

It’s almost like how at one point people prefered to buy a new phone than a used phone because they couldn’t open the phone to check or didn’t know if the battery was good enough to work.

👉🏼 So this is what you should when you are buying an EV:

1/ Ask the manufacturer on what is the warranty on the battery... so that you get at least 10-15 years of working life from the car, such that even if you sell it, the buyer has a warranty on the battery from the manufacturer itself.

It’s said that BYD has now introduced 8 year warranties, and Tata may launch 15 year warranties on some models... but this is only for first owners. Also ask the warranties for second owners.

2/ Ask them if the company has the option to swap the battery if it falls below a particular standard of performance, and if there is Battery as a Service, where you can swap to a new battery.

For example, some MG models are said to have a rental for the battery where you pay a fixed price per kilometer as rent for the battery instead of owning the battery.

3/ And if you have to buy a used EV, please get a Certificate of State of Health (SoH) from the car manufacturer, such that there should not be more than 2% battery loss for every year of the car’s age... and maybe get certified pre-owned to be safe.

Why is suddenly AI being called a bubble? And what kind of financial scam are these AI companies running...

And this concept is playing out among the AI companies too...

Where Nvidia is the father and companies like Open AI are the sons...

These AI companies like Open AI need semiconductor chips to keep their businesses running... which are all supplied by Nvidia... who is also an investor in them...

So Nvidia invests USD 100 Bn in Open AI with a condition that they will buy semiconductor chips from them... 

OpenAI’s valuation increases, Nvidia’s sales increases... and all these companies are now investing in each other and paying money to each other to inflate both their valuations and revenues.

Such that Nvidia has now become the most valuable company in the world... and is at a 30X Revenue Multiple... Open AI is at an almost 40X Revenue Multiple...

And what does Sam Altman have to say about this?

He agrees that the market is in a bubble, but he has to play this game because these AI firms are now competing with each other fiercely and they have no other option.

He has admitted that even the USD 200 per month plan is unprofitable and the cost of compute is higher than the revenue it generates.

Now, how does it impact you?

As an end user of AI tools, it’s a great time because every AI company wants to give you things for free to lock you as a user.

And who is paying the price for this? In a great way, the US stock market investors.

As a customer, enjoy while it lasts. And as an investor, it’s best to be safe and have a balanced portfolio. Don’t go all in on either stocks or gold. Just focus on wealth preservation in uncertain times.

There are 4 foreign countries that are actively inviting Indians with open arms to come and take jobs in these developed countries...

I’m talking about Japan, Germany, Finland, and Taiwan...

👉🏼 Germany is the most desperate for Indians as there are over 700,000 jobs across healthcare, IT, engineering and construction...

So Germany has announced a Focus on India plan last year, by which they now want to issue 90,000 skilled work visas to Indians annually up from 20,000 earlier...

And the average Indian in Germany earns close to Rs 6 lakhs per month

They no longer require an IT worker to have German proficiency, and you may have no degree in software development, and you could still be eligible with two years of coding experience.

Average salaries in IT would range from Rs 40 to 80 lakhs depending on the experience and expertise... and engineers in Pharma and Chemicals are getting on an average close to Rs 70 lakhs per annum.

👉🏼 Japan has just signed an agreement with India by which 500,000 people will be migrating over the next 5 years...

Their focus is on getting engineers and IT professionals... which are said to take up 20% of all IT jobs in Japan... and median salaries are expected to be around Rs 40 lakhs.

Whereas Nurses would make Rs 3-4 lakhs per month.

👉🏼 Finland is offering Permanent Residency to skilled workers who hold a master’s degree and can pass a language exam in Finnish or Swedish...

Indians in Finland have risen by 350% in the past decade, and an EU Blue Card is being offered to skilled workers in healthcare, IT and engineering.

👉🏼 Taiwan wants to import people who can work in manufacturing, and are preferring labour from the North Eastern states due to cultural similarities.

The cost of living is 4X of India... so while your expenses will also go up, but if you save 20% of your salary in India, and 20% in Japan... the savings amount in these countries in absolute terms could be 3X of your India savings.

There are currently more PE firms in the US than McDonald’s...

This shows that there is more profit opportunity in serving financial services to ultra HNIs than to serve simple food to the masses...

50% of all total spending in the US is now done by 10% of the top households... and they have 90% of the investments in the stock market, but only 5% of the household debt... 

And this is not limited to the US... but applies to almost all major economies where wealth inequalities are rising, including in India.

Then what do governments and central banks do to make the masses afford more...

They make interest rates lower to flood the market with more money... and this money goes largely into the hands of the wealthy, who keep driving stock markets and real estate up, while inflation increases for the masses, and they buy more, but with just more debt.

And the masses would have more job security two decades ago, but now the masses live constantly thinking and knowing that a job is possibly just as risky as a business... where they may actually be laid off tomorrow.

In such a case, there are two things you can do:

- If you are starting a business, please create one to cater to the HNIs and premium client only.

- If you are in a job, either you will have to spend hours learning new skills daily.

If you’re planning a holiday for this December, you have to know of these 4 interventions right now that could reduce your total spend by 20–25%...

1/ Look out for countries that are subsidising flight tickets to promote exotic, offbeat destinations.
For example:

Thailand is subsidising tickets for 200k tourists - but only if you skip Bangkok.

Vietnam wants you in Da Nang, not just Hanoi - offering up to 50% discounts on hotels and attractions through its “New Da Nang - New Experience” program.

2/ There are also a few international destinations where travel has become cheaper because the INR is getting stronger against their local currencies.

The biggest wins here are Japan, Vietnam, and Sri Lanka - where you now get 3.5 Sri Lankan Rupees per 1 INR, making a full SL holiday doable within ₹60,000 per person.

3/ Within India, a limited-fare initiative called “One Route, One Fare” is live from October to December on select Alliance Air routes - including Shimla, Diu, Guwahati, and a few other tier-2 cities. Under this scheme, the ticket price stays fixed whether you book months in advance or even on the day of travel.

These points are key because 75% of New Year’s Eve bookings happen in the last three weeks of December, and the first two weeks of November are when stays and flights are roughly 25% cheaper for December vacations.

4/ In November, there is a Travel ka Muhurat Sale being run by MakeMyTrip, launching on 29th of October, to capture all the travel bookings for December. It’s one of the biggest travel sales the industry has seen - with offers like free stays, free upgrades, and 20–25% extra savings across categories.

A little early to say, but happy holidays.

If house prices are so high that no one can afford to buy a house now, will the prices continue to rise, or will real estate prices crash?

Let’s look at some data to understand how this works...

Since 2020, housing prices in India have skyrocketed, rising by almost 10% p.a., while incomes are only rising by about 5% p.a.

Such that the rates are absolutely unaffordable in cities like Mumbai and Gurgaon where you would need anywhere between 20-30 years of income to buy a house...

Currently, all developers are building ultra luxury homes in India...

Such that affordable housing inventory has dropped by 70% in Hyderabad, 60% in Mumbai and 50% in NCR over the past 2 years...

And this is because builders want to make higher margins and cater to a premium customer which is not price sensitive...

And at the same time, institutional investors in Indian real estate have reached almost USD 9 Billion in 2024, which is an over 50% increase from 2023...

And out of these institutions, 63% are foreign investors, while only 37% are Indian institutions.

And from an overall economy perspective, India faces a shortfall of 10 million homes, potentially increasing to 30 million in the next decade...

And here’s what happening right now...

Over the past 6 months, the sales volume of real estate developers has dropped sharply...

But prices are still stable and holding on... so there is no price crash, but currently there is no price increase either...

And because the owners of a lot of the current units are either NRIs, foreign institutional investors, or just the uber rich, they may not be desperate to sell at a loss...

And house prices have never crashed in India earlier on an average, so I’m expecting there to be a multi-year stagnation in price where for the next 2-3 years, you shouldn’t buy in panic that prices will go up...

In fact, know that today, you kind of have an upper hand in negotiating with developers because a number of them are desperate to meet their sales targets.

Blackberry, the mobile company, is not dead... In fact, it is today a market leader with 40% market share... has beaten Apple...

The company powers the operating software that you see on the infotainment panel, digital dashboard, and driver panel in your car... It controls the entire software operations for EVs including advanced driver assistance systems, handsfree communication, and telematics...

For every major auto brand including Mercedes, BMW, Audi, Honda, Toyota, Volkswagen, Hyundai, Kia...

It’s in fact so big that 24 out of the 25 largest EV makers in the world, and the top 10 automakers use it in their car...

Such that over 250 million cars around the world use the Blackberry software called QNX.

And it’s said that today to build an OS for cars is so complex that Boeing airplanes run on 7 million lines of code, but car OS for new EVs run on 500 million lines of code...

And Blackberry has beaten Apple in this domain because Apple has burnt USD 10 Billion in building a similar system, but shut down operations while QNX succeeded.

QNX currently does a lot more software development in medical devices, aerospace and defence, and boats of numbers such as an 80% gross margin and over 30% EBITDA.

While it is no where close to the size of the Blackberry mobile phone business... 

but it’s telling of the fact that there are huge wins and opportunities even when the world thinks something you’ve been working on has been a failure.

*********
I learnt about this because The Ken recently did a story on QNX and went on to see quite a few other publications have been writing about it for quite some time too.

Imagine your child going to school through rivers every morning, studying in classrooms with no benches, and using toilets so broken that they are forced to use jungles.

And yet, these children still show up. They still want to learn. They still have hope.

This isn't just about one village, this is the reality for millions of children across India's remote areas. They deserve better. They deserve safety, proper facilities, and a real chance at education.

Aap kitni baar brush karte ho?👀

The world’s first mass-produced toothbrush was actually made in jail!

In 18th-century Europe, a man named William Addis was jailed for causing a riot.
He hated cleaning his teeth with cloth and ash, so he got an idea from a broom.
Using an animal bone and horse hair, he created a prototype of the modern toothbrush.
But brushing teeth is much older: Egyptians used chew sticks in 3000 BC,
and China made the first bristle toothbrush in the 15th century!

How do you celebrate Diwali?😍

 In Dhami village of Himachal, one day after Diwali, people throw small stones at each other, If someone bleeds, they put a tilak of that blood on Goddess Kali.
 In a Karnataka village, people have a playful fight using cow dung to mark the end of Diwali..
 In Odisha, Diwali is about inviting ancestors, with jute sticks lit to welcome their spirits.
 The Mandyam Iyengar community of Karnataka  mourns Diwali, remembering families lost in the 18th century due to Tipu Sultan.

Don’t come to the USA unless you read this…..

If you’re considering the US for your masters/bachelors, don’t come here if you

1️⃣ are not ready to study hard throughout your course

↬ assignments, tests, quizzes, exams - you can’t skip any

↬ they all add & make up your class grades

↬ it’s not just the final exams like India

2️⃣ haven’t got your roommates sorted out

↬ the wrong people will ruin your journey abroad

↬ switching apartments is a big pain, so take your time

↬ from sharing rent to house chores, you’ll do it all next 2 years.

3️⃣ can’t deal with loneliness & homesickness

↬ social media only gives you half the picture about the US

↬ loneliness can cripple you if you aren’t prepared for it

↬ be mentally prepared. This is going to be hard for you

4️⃣ are not ready to fight for On-campus jobs

↬ start networking before to know more about openings

↬ come with a financial plan; don’t just depend on the job

5️⃣ can’t take the uncertainty of job search

↬ be prepared to take 100s of rejections on your journey

↬ you’ll only have 90 days to crack an offer, be ready

6️⃣ can’t take care of yourself

↬ you’ll be on your own for the next 2 years.

The life of an international student is a battle each day, nothing will come easy.

But when you finally make it, nothing ever comes close to that happiness & satisfaction.

Good luck & Plan well, dreamer 💗

The top 5 most expensive cities to live in the United States in 2025, especially relevant for Indian immigrants considering factors like housing, rent, and overall living costs, are:

1. New York City, New York
2. San Francisco, California
3. San Jose, California
4. Seattle, Washington
5. Boston, Massachusetts

Here is the same list with their monthly average expenses

New York City: $5,800

San Francisco: $4,800

San Jose: $4,700

Seattle: $4,100

Boston: $4,000

New York City: Monthly expenses around $6,000 include high rents averaging $4,000-$5,600 plus food, transport, and utilities adding $1,500-$2,000.

San Francisco: Monthly costs of about $5,800 driven by sky-high home prices near $1.5 million and premium lifestyle expenses.

San Jose: Requires approximately $6,200 monthly due to the highest home prices in the US, averaging around $1.6 million, with tech-sector wages pushing costs up.

Seattle: Living comfortably costs about $4,500 monthly with housing averaging $750,000 and additional costs for transportation and daily needs.

Boston: Monthly expenses near $4,800 reflect costly housing (~$820,000 median home price), plus living expenses typical of a major metro with strong education and healthcare sectors.

and if it’s the other way around, it can even change your life.
