The U.S. government will now send immigration officers straight to your house, without warning.

If you’re on an F-1 visa and working under OPT

The Trump administration has increased random checks on foreign students working under STEM OPT, where you’re allowed to work for up to 3 years after graduation.

These visits are done by the Fraud Detection and National Security (FDNS) unit along with ICE to verify whether you’re:
→ working in your field of study
→ maintaining valid F-1 status
→ and following all federal rules

Students have reported officers showing up without notice and asking for ID and work authorization, Offer letter and otherJob-related proof

And here’s the scary part: Even small mistakes or missing documents can become a big visa concern

So if you’re on OPT or STEM-OPT:
✅ Keep your Form I-983 fully updated
✅ Report any job or address change immediately
✅ Stay calm and cooperative during checks

Also, RFEs (Requests for Evidence) are increasing especially when students change jobs or lose one.

And since Indian students form the largest group under STEM-OPT, they’re the most affected right now.

DHS Ends Automatic Extension of Employment Authorization

Trump’s new rule could make thousands of immigrants lose their job in America

The USCIS just dropped a new “interim final rule.” and here’s what’s happening:

Every immigrant needs a work permit called the *EAD,* to legally work in the U.S.

Until now, if you were on H4 EAD or AOS EAD, the government gave you a grace period upto 540 days to work while your renewal was being processed.

but starting October 30th 2025, once your EAD expires, your work permit expires with it.

USCIS says this is to “strengthen vetting and protect national security.”

This will Mainly affect H-4 EAD holders, adjustment-of-status applicants, and a few other visa categories that used to get this automatic grace period.

So, skilled immigrants, green card applicants and even spouses of H-1B workers may lose their jobs for no fault of their own.

Note that If you’re on OPT or STEM OPT, this likely doesn’t apply to you.

Also, If you file your EAD renewal before October 30, 2025, you’ll still be covered under the old 540-day rule.

So if your EAD is expiring anytime in late 2025 or early 2026, file early and renew your work permit atleast 6 months before expiry.

Track your case status regularly and Avoid job gaps by alerting your employer in advance.

This doesn’t apply to STEM extension EADs so all my f1 students you are fine. 

And by the way, I'm not an immigration lawyer. This was actually discussed in my latest session with Sameer, who's an immigration lawyer. If you want to watch the full session comment below EAD and I’ll send it to you

Let’s say you want to buy a Tesla Model Y today in America.

It’s going to cost you roughly $49,489 after all the taxes, etc.

Today’s interest rate is roughly 6.5% or so, and based on that, your car payments are going to be roughly $750–$800/month depending on your down payment.

On top of that, you also have to pay insurance and some electricity charges.

Let’s assume that will be another $540 per month.

So that’s about $1,300 a month, which is roughly $15,600 a year.

Typically, I would recommend that your car payment is less than 10-15% of your income,

which means you need to make around $90,000 to $100,000 a year in salary.

U.S. Job Hunting Series - Episode 5

Here’s what to avoid on your resume if you want to stand out to recruiters and hiring managers:

- Skip the “Objective” section because they already know your goal is to get hired.
- Instead, write a professional summary that highlights your experience, skills, and impact.

- Don’t include your full address — your email and phone number are enough for recruiters to contact you.

- Add your education only if you have less than five years of experience, and move it to the bottom.

- Structure your resume in this order: Work Experience, Projects, Skills, Education, and Leadership.

- Under each role, include 3–5 bullet points showing what you did and the measurable results you achieved.

Remember: Recruiters scan resumes in an F-pattern, so layout and formatting matter more than you think.

America’s entry-level jobs are disappearing and you’ll be shocked to know why.

Recently Emily Glassberg Sands, who leads Data Science at Stripe, recently said she’s hiring more new graduates than ever before.

But even with all that, she says that she’s worried.

In 2025 AI tools like ChatGPT, can do many of those beginner tasks faster and cheaper.

Companies are letting AI handle the easy work that used to teach new workers how to get better.

So even though companies are still hiring, the types of jobs that actually teach you how to grow are quietly disappearing.

Emily said she’s not afraid of hiring new talent but she’s afraid of what happens after.

Because without mentorship, without seniors to guide, review, and correct, we’ll have a generation that knows the tools but would lack skills.

Even AI leaders like Anthropic’s CEO warn that automation could wipe out a large share of entry-level white-collar jobs in the next few years.

So if you’re starting your career, you’ll need to build your own projects, network with people and use AI as a teacher, not just a tool.

so what do you think? will AI replace entry level jobs or entry level learning?

🚢💼 Bharat Ka Export Dream: Kahan Hai Raasta? 🇮🇳🌏

Arre yaar, sab export-export ki baat karte hain, par kya export karein aur kahan? 🤔

Did you know? India’s exports hit a whopping $447 billion in 2022-23! 📈 Par abhi bhi bohot scope hai, dosto!

Yeh raha asli scene:
• 1.3 billion logon ka desh, par sirf 1% companies export karti hain! 😱
• Top exports: Petroleum products, diamonds, pharma... boring nahi lag raha? 💎💊

Naye entrepreneurs ke liye golden chances:
1. Handicrafts: $3.5 billion ka market, growing fast! 🎨
2. Organic food: Global demand 16% annually badh raha hai! 🥕
3. Software services: $150 billion ka export... aur badhta hi ja raha hai! 💻

Par problem kya hai?
• 63% SMEs ko nahi pata export kaise karein! 🤦‍♂️
• 76% ko international standards ke baare mein knowledge nahi! 📚
• 54% ko funding ki dikkat! 💸

Government schemes toh hain:
• Make in India 🏭
• Production Linked Incentive Scheme 💰
• District as Export Hub 🏙️

Par real talk? Implementation mein gadbad hai! 😅

Kuch cool facts:
• India is world’s largest exporter of... wait for it... FROGS’ LEGS! 🐸 (Yup, France ko supply karte hain!)
• Our Alphonso mangoes are banned in Japan... kyunki wahan ke beetles ko pasand hai! 🥭🪲

Ab batao, tum kya export karoge? Apne unique Indian product ka idea comments mein share karo! 👇

Aur haan, agar tumhe bhi export ke baare mein zyada pata nahi, toh tension not! You’re not alone. Let’s figure this out together! 💪

Which Product Exporting from Different Cities of Gujrat, Import Export Business, City wise knowledge.
Let’s find out which products are exported from which cities in Gujarat:
- Ahmedabad exports garments, pharmaceuticals, machinery, and Jewellery.
- Surat exports diamonds, textiles, and garment products.
- Rajkot exports engineering goods, plastic bottles, Jewellery, and kitchenware products.
- Bharuch and Ankleshwar export chemical products.
- Morbi exports ceramic tiles, ceramic products, and clocks.
- Kutch exports handicrafts and salt.

So, you can also start your export journey by selecting any product available around you and exporting it.

If I transferred  INR 10 Crores to your bank account would you still go to office tomorrow? 🤔

More than 90% of people would say “No, I’ll start something of my own and be my own boss” The truth is most of us don’t like our jobs but do it only coz it pays the bills 💸 

You are forced to work at companies that pay you the highest salaries not because you want to but because money controls you. 

Even if we divided all the money in the world equally among 8 Billion people, the world would still go back to how it is today. Survival of the fittest is the law of the jungle and in today’s world if you don’t know how money works then you’ve already lost 💪🏻 

Unfortunately, this is conveniently not taught to us in schools and that is the reason I created @onepercentclub . 

We are currently India’s only and largest school of Money with over 50,000 members and on our 2nd year anniversary we are launching our first ever brand film. Hope you enjoy it as much as I enjoyed creating it 🙏🏻

Many people wonder what to do with unused credit cards. While closing may look like the easy choice, it can hurt your credit score by reducing your credit limit, shortening your credit history, and weakening your credit mix.

 Here’s the smarter way to think about it:
When Closing Makes Sense:
The card has high annual fees and doesn’t give enough value.
Too many cards are tempting you to overspend.
You’re worried about security risks on an idle card.
If none of these apply, keeping the card open is often better.

Smarter Option: Downgrade Instead of Closing
If fees are the only problem, don’t cancel.
Ask your bank to downgrade to a lifetime free / zero-fee version.
This keeps your credit history and limit intact, while saving you money.
No hard inquiry is triggered, unlike applying for a brand-new card.
Best of both worlds: low cost + strong score.

If You Must Cancel, Do It Right
Clear all dues before closure.
Redeem reward points or cashback.
Keep your oldest card open to protect credit history.
Reduce balances on other cards so your utilisation doesn’t spike.
Check your credit report to confirm “closed by customer.

Bottom line: Don’t rush to cut your cards, manage them smartly, and they’ll manage your credit score for you.

Banks won’t like this video… but after RBI’s new rule, your home loan interest might drop again!

Let me explain 👇

In June this year, RBI reduced the repo rate by 50 basis points, which lowered EMIs — but only for those with floating-rate loans, i.e., loans where interest changes when the RBI’s repo rate changes.

But now, RBI has announced a big update that lets everyone reduce their loan interest.

Whenever you take a loan, the interest rate is made up of two parts:

IRS (Internal Reference Rate) — based on your loan repayment term
+ Spread — extra margin added by the bank based on your credit score

So, the better your credit score, the lower your spread and interest rate.

Earlier, banks were allowed to change this spread only once every 3 years, which meant even if your credit score improved, your EMI stayed the same.

But from 1st October, RBI has removed this restriction!
Now you can tell your bank:
👉 “My credit score has improved — please revise my interest rate.”

And if your bank refuses, you can simply transfer your loan to another bank offering a lower rate.

Over the years, this small step can save you lakhs of rupees in interest! 💰

So check your credit score today — and share this video so more people can benefit from this RBI update. 🚀

💡 The Hidden SSY Rule That Most Parents Don’t Know!

Both Rich Dad and Poor Dad invested the same amount in Sukanya Samriddhi Yojana (SSY) at the same interest rate.
But still, Rich Dad earned more returns.

👉 How?

Because Rich Dad knew the secret timing rule of SSY!

📌 What is SSY?
	•	SSY is a government-backed savings scheme for the girl child.
	•	It offers a fixed interest rate (currently ~8.2% per annum in 2025).
	•	It is 100% risk-free and also comes with tax benefits under Section 80C.

🔑 The Secret Rule: Start your SSY investments Before 5th of the Month”

Interest in SSY is calculated on the lowest balance between the 5th and the last day of the month.

➡️ This means:
	•	If you deposit money on or before the 5th, you earn interest for the full month.
	•	If you deposit after the 5th, that month’s interest is lost on that amount.

📊 Example:
	•	Suppose you deposit ₹1,00,000 on 4th October → You earn interest for the whole of October.
	•	But if you deposit ₹1,00,000 on 6th October → You earn zero interest for October on that money.

Over 15–20 years, this small difference every month compounds into lakhs of extra earnings!

✅ The Rich Dad Hack:

Always start investment in SSY on or before the 5th of every month.
That’s the difference between ordinary returns and Rich Dad returns

Term insurance under the Married Women’s Property Act (MWPA) offers many benefits such as : 

- Protection from Creditors: The policy proceeds are shielded from creditors, meaning that even if you have outstanding debts, the insurance amount will reach your beneficiaries without being seized to settle loans.

- Protection from Relatives : The policy proceeds are protected from relatives or other individuals who may have claims on your assets, ensuring that your wife and children receive the intended benefits.

-Legal Protection: The MWPA policy cannot be attached by courts to repay outstanding debts or loans, and the beneficiaries have sole authority over the policy proceeds.

If you have a Term Insurance or plan to purchase new :

1. Check with your insurance company for MWPA coverage
2. Get your policy covered under MWPA

And make the most important decision of your life right.

Save the post so that you don’t forget this.

Banks don’t tell you this. 

In the early years, almost your entire EMI goes towards interest, not the principal. That’s why even small prepayments can save you lakhs. 

Thankfully, RBI has also removed prepayment penalties on floating-rate loans. 

so whenever you have surplus cash, use it to cut your loan tenure short. 
Plus, don’t forget the tax perks: up to ₹1.5 lakh on principal repayment (Sec 80C) and up to ₹2 lakh on interest (Sec 24b). 

First-time homebuyers even get additional deductions.

Now, here’s how you can finish a 25-year loan in just 10 years 👇

Strategy 1: Pay 1 extra EMI every year. 

Instead of 12, pay 13 EMIs—this directly reduces your principal. Result: Loan tenure drops from 25 years to 21 years.

Strategy 2: Increase your EMI by 7.5% annually. 
Year 1 = ₹33,000, Year 2 = ₹36,000, Year 3 = ₹38,000, and so on. As your salary grows, your EMI grows too. Result: Tenure shrinks from 25 years to 12 years.

Strategy 3 (Best): Combine both: pay 1 extra EMI + increase EMI by 7.5% every year. 
This aggressively reduces your principal and slashes interest. Result: Loan tenure cut from 25 years to just 10 years.

Bottom line: Banks design loans so that you end up paying 2.5x the loan amount if you stick to their schedule. 
But with these smart strategies, you can become debt-free 15 years earlier, save lakhs in interest, and enjoy financial freedom for your dreams, investments, and family.
And one last tip, on loan closure, the bank must return your original property documents within 30 days. If they delay, RBI allows you to claim ₹5,000 per day as penalty. 

Always collect a no-dues certificate and ensure your loan account shows zero balance.

Don’t just compare interest rates, check hidden charges, reset frequency, and tenure flexibility. A well-structured home loan not only saves money but also secures your financial peace of mind.

Yeh purana stock hai, isliye naye rate nahi lagenge

But here’s the truth every consumer should know:

 👉 GST is applied on the bill date, not on the stock. That means if you buy something on or after 22nd September 2025 it must carry the reduced GST.

 👉 As per the rules under Legal Metrology & GST Act MRPs on packaged goods must be revised or re-labeled to reflect lower prices. Sellers can even display dual prices (old MRP + revised MRP) but they cannot charge you the higher one.

 👉 Section 171 of the CGST Act 2017 clearly states any reduction in GST must be passed on to the consumer. Keeping that benefit is illegal profiteering.
What you should do as a smart consumer:

Always check your bill date when you shop after 22 Sept.

Look at the MRP label. If it hasn’t been revised ask for clarification.

If you’re still charged extra file a complaint on the National Consumer Helpline 1800-11-4000.

And if you’re wondering which products got cheaper and which ones costlier after 22nd Sept
 Comment “LIST” and I’ll share the full list of goods and revised GST rates with you.

Your small action protects not just your own money but also ensures businesses don’t misuse the system.

When we start early, every stage becomes an opportunity to shape their financial habits:

🧒 Early Years (2–6) → Play money, piggy banks, and learning needs vs wants.
👧 Middle Years (7–12) → Pocket money, savings goals, and making smart shopping choices.
👩 Teen Years (13–18) → Budgeting, supervised bank accounts, basics of investing, and part-time work to respect hard-earned money.

🌱 And through it all—children mirror what they see. If we save, budget, and spend wisely, they will too.

The real gift isn’t just teaching them how to spend or save—it’s teaching them that money represents time, effort, patience, and values. That discipline > income, and gratitude > greed.

Because when kids learn to value money early, they’re not just preparing for wealth—they’re preparing for life.

Looking for short-term investment options that give FD-like safety but with better flexibility and returns? 

Here can be your best picks 👇

1. Liquid Fund

Got idle money for a few days or weeks? Don’t let it sit in your bank!
 Park it in a Liquid Fund → safe, flexible & gives ~5–7% annual returns.
 Perfect for 1 day – 1 month.
 Better than savings account, almost no risk.

2. Short-Term Debt Fund

Need to park money for 1–3 months?
 Go for Short-Term Debt Funds.
 They invest in corporate & govt bonds → giving ~6–8% annual return with low risk.
 More rewarding than FD for short horizons!

3. Medium-Term Debt Fund

Have a 3–12 month horizon?
 Medium-Term Debt Funds can be a smart pick.
 Return potential: 7–8% annually.
 Slightly higher risk than FDs but great for short-term planning.

4. Corporate Bond Fund

Planning for 1–3 years?
 Invest in Corporate Bond Funds → they put money in AAA-rated company bonds.
 Return potential: 8–10% annually with low risk.
 Safer than direct corporate deposits, more rewarding than FDs.

5. Equity Mutual Fund

For 3+ years, nothing beats Equity Mutual Funds.
 Direct stock exposure, long-term compounding → 12–15% average return over time.
 Short term = risky, but long term = wealth creator.
 Best for long-term goals like buying a house, child education, or retirement.

Buying a ₹2 crore flat in cash may feel “safe”… 

but it can actually cost you crores. My friend did this, and lost out on ~₹2.35 crore of profit.

If instead, she had taken a ₹1.8 crore home loan (20 years @ ~8%) and invested the remaining ₹1.8 crore at ~7% return, that investment would have grown to ₹6.97 crore. 

After paying back the loan (₹3.6 crore), she’d still keep ~₹3.37 crore net profit.
Plus, home loans give powerful tax benefits: up to ₹2 lakh interest deduction (Sec 24b), and ₹1.5 lakh principal deduction (Sec 80C). 

Even after capital gains tax, she’d still be in profit.

Lesson? Don’t block your entire money in a flat. Use the bank’s money, invest smartly, and let compounding work for you.

Middle class fear loans. The rich leverage them to get richer. 💡

Did you know?

• Education loans in India start from around 7–9% p.a., much lower than personal loans.
• Under Section 80E of the Income Tax Act, you can claim a full deduction on the interest paid, with no upper limit, for up to 8 years.

Why this is powerful:

You borrow ₹15 lakh at ~9% interest → get interest deduction, bringing your effective rate down to about 6–6.5%.
Meanwhile, you park your ₹15 lakh in a safe FD or debt fund earning 7–7.5% → net gain of 1–1.5%, plus tax savings, plus credit score boost, plus repayment flexibility.

Key takeaways:

Education loans can actually be cheaper than you think.

Section 80E makes them even smarter—maximizing your returns.

Smart borrowing beats draining your savings.

Use it wisely, don’t miss EMIs, and grow credit while you grow your child’s future.

cheeesy spicyyy fries bowl 🧀🍟🌶️

recipe ⬇️ 

peri peri chicken: 

1. Chicken thigh - 500gms 
2. Ginger garlic paste - 2tsp
3. Egg- 1 
4. Milk- 1.5 cups
5. Red chilli powder - 2 tsp 
6. Salt 
7. Maida - 1 cup
8. Cornflour - 1/2 cup
9. Oil - to fry
10. Peri peri 

- Make a marinade by mixing egg, milk, ginger-garlic paste, red chilli powder, and salt.
- Marinate the chicken in this mixture.
- In another bowl, mix maida and cornflour.
- Coat the chicken in the flour mixture, dip it back into the marinade, and coat it again with the flour.
- Deep fry till it’s crispy on the outside and tender inside.
- Mix peri peri powder with a little oil and brush it over the fried chicken.
- Slice into strips and keep aside.

cheese sauce:
1. Butter- 2tsp
2. Maida - 1.5tsp 
3. Milk - 1 cup 
4. Cheese - 3-4 cubes 
5. Chilli sauce - 2 tbsp
6. Turmeric powder - 1/4 tsp 
- Cook the maida in butter for a minute.
- Add the milk in two instalments, whisking continuously.
- Add the grated cheese and whisk until you get a smooth, lump-free sauce.
- Optionally, add chilli sauce and turmeric powder. You can also add 1/2 tsp garlic paste for extra flavour.

jeera rice:

- Whisk dahi with salt, red chilli powder, aamchur powder, and water.
- Add the boiled and chopped potatoes along with sliced onions and coriander leaves.
- Heat some oil in a pan on low heat, add kasuri methi, turmeric powder, and red chilli powder.

baingan bhaja:

4. Coriander powder

- Mix milk and vinegar and let it sit for 10 minutes till it curdles.
- Add in the rest of the wet ingredients — curd, castor sugar, brown sugar, oil and vanilla — and mix till smooth.
- Sift in all the dry ingredients and gently fold.
- Now mix hot water with coffee and add it to the batter, give it a gentle mix.
- Transfer to a lined tray and bake at 180°C for 20–25 minutes.

Biscoff cheesecake filling:
1. Cream cheese - 200g 
2. Biscoff filling- 100g 
3. Icing sugar- 30g 
4. Whipping cream - 50g 
- Whisk cream cheese till smooth and lump-free.
- Add Biscoff spread and icing sugar, mix till well combined.
- In another bowl, whip 50g cream till soft peaks.
- Gently fold the whipped cream into the cream cheese mixture.

Chocolate ganache:
1. Dark chocolate- 70g 
2. Fresh cream - 70g 
- Add chopped dark chocolate to a bowl.
- Pour warm fresh cream over it and mix until the chocolate melts and you get a smooth, glossy ganache.

easy & moist orange cake 🍊 

recipe ⬇️ 

Makes 1 loaf cake 
Ingredients: 
1. Castor sugar- 150 gms
2. Orange zest - 2 oranges 
3. Eggs - 2 
4. Unsalted Butter — 55g
5. Oil- 50g
6. Milk- 75g 
7. Orange juice- 15ml 
8. Yogurt- 70g 
9. Refined flour- 220 
10. Baking powder- 5g
11. Baking soda- 3g
12. Salt- 3g

- Rub the castor sugar and orange zest together.
- In a separate bowl, mix the butter, oil, milk, orange juice, and yogurt.
- Sift the dry ingredients (flour, baking soda, baking powder, and salt) and set aside.
- Whisk the egg and sugar until light and fluffy.
- Add half of the dry ingredients and whisk, then add half of the wet ingredients and whisk again. Add the remaining dry and wet ingredients, gently whisking until just combined. (If you add all the wet ingredients at once, lumps may form.) Do not overmix the batter.
- Pour the batter into a lined and greased tin.
- Bake at 180°C for 35 minutes. If you’re baking it in an airfryer, cover the top using a foil paper. 
- Poke holes in the cake and soak with orange juice.
- Finish with the orange glaze on top.

Orange Glaze: 
1. Fresh orange juice – 15 g
2. Icing sugar – 120g
- Mix the sifted icing sugar with the orange juice.
- If the glaze feels too runny, add more icing sugar; if it feels too thick, add a few more drops of orange juice.

Gond ke Laddu Recipe ⤵️

Postpartum Essentials Episode 3: Gondh ke Laddoo 🌰

Ingredients 
150 g desi ghee
100 g gond
1 cup makhana
50 g cashew nuts 
50 g almonds
50 g raisins
50 g dessicated coconut 
2 tbsp melon seeds
2.5 tbsp besan
250 g wholewheat flour 
200 g jaggery
1/4 cup water 
1 tsp cardamom powder
1 tsp ginger pwd
1 tsp Ajwain 

- In a pan add some ghee and fry the gond in batches till doubled in volume & crisp. Set aside
- In the same pan fry the makhana in ghee till crispy
- Crush the gond and makhana together 
- Now fry the almonds, cashews and raisins in ghee till fragrant & crisp. Then crush in a food processor till fine & mix with the crushed makhana
- In the pan roast the coconut & melon seeds in some ghee till golden & fragrant. Mix this with the dry fruits 
- In the pan add more ghee and toast the besan on medium flame till fragrant (mixing constantly to avoid burning)
- Add the remaining ghee and the wholewheat flour to this and roast till light brown & fragrant 
- Add Ajwain, cardamom & ginger powder. Mix this with the crushed dry fruits 
- In a pan add 1 tbsp ghee, jaggery & water. Cook on medium flame till a smooth syrup forms. Let it cool a little 
- Add the jaggery syrup in the nuts mixture and mix well by hands. It should clump together and have a soft ball consistency 
- Make laddus while the mixture is still warm and store in airtight containers

DISCLAIMER: None of these items have any scientific evidence to start, speed up or shorten labour. It is just based on anecdotes or folktales. Since there was no harm in trying, I decided to give it a shot!

I also paired these with lots of exercises, walk & a general active lifestyle ⚠️ Always consult your doctor before introducing any foods in your diet or starting any exercise!

1. Cinnamon 🥣 : One of the most common spices believed to induce labour pains. It has a calming effect however it is not a proven method for induction
2. Fresh pineapple 🍍 : It contains the enzyme bromelain & common belief is that it helps to soften the cervix & encourage contractions. Eat about 1 cup pineapple per day (canned will not work!)
3. Dates 🌴: They contain fiber & prostaglandins which may help ripen & dilate the cervix shortening the first stage of labour & increasing the likelihood of spontaneous labour. Aim to eat 6 dates a day!
4. Papaya 🥭: Unripe or semi-ripe papaya can induce labor due to its high concentration of latex & the enzyme papain that can cause uterine contractions. I ate ripe papaya & wasn’t too regular with it!
5. Raspberry Leaf Tea ☕️ : It tones uterine muscles leading to more effective contractions, shortens the first stage of labour & may reduce delivery interventions. I had about 3 to 4 cups per day!

RECIPE ⬇️⤵️

Everyday Healthy Episode 9 - Chicken Cheese Buns 🍔

Dough
2 cups flour
1½ tsp instant yeast
1 egg
½ tsp salt
1 tbsp caster sugar
1 tbsp yogurt
1½ tbsp oil
lukewarm water as required

• Mix all the ingredients and make a medium soft dough
• Cover with cling wrap and let it proof for 1 to 2 hours in a dark, warm place till doubled in volume
• Then divide the dough in 6 to 7 balls and set aside covered with a damp cloth

Chicken Fajita Filling
300 g chicken cubes
1 tsp kashmiri red chilli powder 
½ tsp paprika 
¾ tsp cumin pwd
½ tsp onion pwd
1 tsp garlic pwd
1 tsp salt
½ tsp coriander pwd
¾ tsp sugar
½ tbsp cornflour 
1 small onion sliced
1 small capsicum julienne 
Handful frozen corn
1½ cups mozzarella cheese 

• In a pan add olive oil & the chicken
• Add all the spices and cook the chicken 
• Add the Cornflour, onion, capsicum and corn
• Mix only till the vegetables are sauteed but still crunchy

Assembly
• Roll the dough balls and place over a frying strainer 
• Add 2 to 3 tbsp filling and handful cheese
• With soft hands carefully seal the buns. Make sure there are no openings 
• Place on baking paper and let them proof again for 20 - 30 minutes till doubled
• Then brush with egg. Add sesame seeds
• Bake in preheated oven at 180°C for 20 to 25 min till the buns are nicely browned

Vanilla Tea Cake Recipe ⤵️

Sweater Weather: Bakery Style Tea Cake 🌙

Recipe
200 g salted butter (softened)
200 g caster sugar 
4 eggs
200 g flour 
1.5 tsp baking powder 
1 tsp vanilla essence 
100 ml buttermilk 
1 drop yellow food colour (optional)

- preheat the oven to 180C. Grease & line a 9 inch loaf pan with parchment paper
- In a bowl sift together the flour & baking powder 
- In a bowl beat the butter till pale, light & fluffy
- Add in one egg & 1 tbsp prepared flour. Beat well. In this way add in all the 4 eggs 
- Now add the vanilla & the remaining flour. Fold with a spatula
- Add the buttermilk & food colour if using. Fold well till the batter is medium thin consistency 
- Transfer to your prepared pan and score in the middle with a knife 
- Bake in the oven for 30 to 40 minutes till a skewer inserted in the center comes out clean 
- Let it cool before cutting

Bone Broth (Yakhni) Recipe ⤵️

Postpartum Essentials Episode 2: Yakhni or Bone Broth 🍖

Ingredients 
1 kg beef or mutton bones (I used a mix of knuckles, marrow bones, rib bones)
2 onions cut in chunks
1 bulb garlic, halved 
2 inches ginger
1 chopped carrot 
Handful fresh herbs (parsley, dill or coriander)
2 bay leaves 
1/2 tsp peppercorns
1 stick cinnamon
1 tsp cumin seeds 
Few cloves 
1 tsp fennel seeds
1/2 tsp oregano
1 tbsp salt
1 tsp turmeric
2 tbsp apple cider vinegar 
Water as required 

- preheat the oven to 180 C
- wash the bones thoroughly & arrange on a baking tray
- Roast them in the oven for 30 to 40 minutes till brown & fragrant 
- Transfer to a large pot & add all the remaining ingredients
- Bring this to a rolling boil then reduce the heat to the lowest
- Cook for 12 to 24 hours stirring occasionally (for a runnier broth, you may top up with some water)
- Once cooked, remove the bones carefully & strain the broth 
- Refrigerate for at least 4 to 5 hours
- Carefully remove the layer of beef tallow on top & store for later use 
- The broth/jelly at the bottom is to be reheated as required. Add some salt & lemon juice to season & enjoy warm

Panjeeri Recipe ⤵️

Postpartum Essentials Episode 1: Panjiri 🥥

Ingredients 
1 cup desi ghee
½ cup almonds
½ cup cashews
½ cup walnuts
¼ pistachios
½ cup pumpkin seeds
½ cup melons seeds
3 tbsp flaxseeds
2 tbsp aliv seeds
1/4 cup golden raisins 
½ cup edible gum (Gond)
3.5 cup Lotus seeds (makhana)
1.5 cups grated coconut
1½ cup semolina (suji)
200 g jaggery or caster sugar 
3 tbsp water 
1 tsp cardamom powder
1 tsp ginger pwd
1 tsp fennel pwd 

- In a pan add some ghee and toast the nuts, seeds & raisins till fragrant & crisp
- Remove 1/4 cup of nuts from this and set aside 
- Crush the remaining nuts in a food processor in large chunks (not fine powder). Set aside 
- In a pan add ghee and fry the gond in batches till doubled in volume & crispy 
- In the same pan add more ghee and fry the makhana till crispy 
- Remove 1/4 cup makhana and 1/4 cup fried Gond. Grind the remaining together. Mix this in the crushed nuts 
- In a pan add more ghee and toast the semolina on medium flame till golden & fragrant (mixing constantly to avoid burning)
- In the last 5 min add the coconut and toast till golden 
- Mix this with the crushed nuts. Add fennel, cardamom & ginger powder 
- In a pan add 1 tbsp ghee, jaggery & water. Cook on medium flame till a smooth syrup forms
- Let this cool to room temperature 
- Add the jaggery syrup in the nuts mixture and mix well by hands
- Decorate the panjeeri with reserved whole nuts, makhana & Gond. Store in airtight jar in the refrigerator

A full day of eating 🥣 

Let me know what recipes you want to see on the feed!

- Immunity Shots to start the day - vibrant, comforting & good for the soul 😌 The recipe is on my feed!
- Breakfast was a chocolate oatmeal bowl - I always add an extra egg white in my oatmeal for added protein. You can’t even tell & it’s just yum!
- Lunch was rice paper dumplings 🥟 Just cooked cabbage & carrots with chicken mince. Added some basic sauces like soy & oyster followed by green onions. Served with homemade chilli oil dipping sauce 🥵
- Dinner was 20 minutes cholay masala with a spicy yogurt sauce. I used canned chickpeas and had that with leftover dumpling filling. Protein 💪🏻💪🏻
- Dessert (because I need that!): Bluebs dipped in 70% dark choc & frozen. I can eat ALL in one go! 🤤

Savoury Oatmeal Bowl Recipe ⤵️

30 Minute Meals Episode 11 - Savory Oatmeal 🥣 

Recipe
1 tbsp butter
1 tbsp crushed garlic 
1/4 cup onion chopped
1/2 cup rolled oats
3/4 cup chicken stock/vegetable stock/water
Salt to taste 
1/2 tsp black pepper
1/4 tsp oregano 
Handful mozzarella cheese 
1/4 cup sliced green onions 

For serving 🍲
Soft boiled egg
Sautéed mushrooms
Blanched broccoli 
Chilli oil
Green onions
Sesame seeds

- In a pan melt the butter & fry the garlic 
- Then add the onion & sauté till softened
- Add the oats and toast till fragrant 
- Add the chicken stock & mix well. cook on medium flame till the oats soften & thicken but are still saucy 
- Add the spices, cheese and green onions. Mix well
- Serve hot with toppings of your choice

Chicken Makhni Handi Recipe ⤵️

30 Minute Meals Episode 10 - Restaurant Style Chicken Makhani Handi 🥘

Recipe
2 tbsp butter
1 tbsp ghee
1 small onion finely chopped
300 g boneless chicken cubes 
1 tbsp ginger garlic paste 
1/2 tsp turmeric 
1 tsp coriander powder
1/2 tsp cumin pwd 
3/4 tsp Kashmiri red chilli pwd 
3/4 tsp black pepper
1 tsp salt
1/2 tsp garam masala 
1.5 tomatoes blended with 1 tbsp tomato paste 
2 tbsp heap yogurt 
1/4 cup water 
3 tbsp cream 
1 tsp Kasuri Methi crushed 
2 chopped green chillies 
Chopped coriander 
Ginger julienne 

- In a pan melt the butter & ghee then add the onion. Fry till golden brown 
- Add the chicken & ginger garlic paste. Fry till the chicken turns white 
- Add all the spices and tomato puree. Mix well 
- Add the yogurt and water. Cover and cook on medium flame till the oil separates 
- Now add the cream, kasuri methi, green chillies and coriander. Mix well
- Cover and cook for 2 - 3 more minutes till the gravy is well combined
- Serve hot with naan or roti

Mushroom Duplex Recipe ⤵️

30 Minute Meals Episode 9 - Mushroom Duplex 🍄‍🟫

Recipe
250 g fresh button mushrooms 
1/4 onion
1/4 capsicum 
3 garlic cloves crushed
1 tbsp butter 
1/2 tsp salt
1/2 tsp black pepper
1/2 tsp oregano
1/2 tsp chilli flakes 
1/3 cup spinach
1 tbsp chopped parsley (can use dried)
1/4 cup grated cheddar cheese

Coating 
2 tbsp flour + 2 tbsp cornflour mixed with water to form a slurry 
Breadcrumbs 

- Wash the mushroom thoroughly and remove the stems
- Add half the stems in a chopper along with onions & capsicum. Chop till fine pieces 
- In a pan melt the butter & fry the garlic 
- Add the chopped veggies and fry till softened 
- Add the spices, spinach and parsley. Mix well
- Let the filling cool for 5 min then mix with cheddar cheese 
- Stuff this inside a mushroom cavity and close with another mushroom of the same size
- Secure with two toothpicks 
- Dip in flour slurry followed by breadcrumbs. Repeat for a crisper coating 
- Freeze for 5 minutes then Fry in medium hot oil till golden brown 
- Slice in half and serve hot with sweet chilli sauce

Shadi Wala Red Chicken Recipe ⤵️

Hyderabadi Food Series Episode 16: ShadiWala Red Chicken 🍗

Ingredients (Serves 4)
Chicken Marination 🥘
750 g chicken with bone
100 g yogurt
2 tbsp ginger garlic paste 
1 tbsp green chilli paste 
1/2 tsp shahzeera
1.5 tbsp Kashmiri red chilli pwd 
1.5 tsp coriander pwd
1 tsp salt
1 tsp garam masala pwd
1/2 tsp cumin pwd 
1 tomato blended with 1 tbsp tomato paste 
2 medium onions golden fried, crushed 
5 cashews & 5 almonds (soaked then blended with 2 cardamoms)
1/4 cup onion oil 

Sauces 
1 tbsp soy sauce 
2 tbsp ketchup 
1 tbsp green chilli sauce
1 tbsp red chilli sauce 
1 tbsp vinegar 
1/2 tsp red food colour 

For cooking
1/4 cup ghee
8 to 10 curry leaves 
2 green chillies slit 
Chopped coriander 
3/4 tsp black pepper 

- Marinade the chicken with all the listed ingredients & sauces for at least 1 hour 
- In a pan add the ghee and curry leaves. Add in the chicken & mix well
- Add 1/2 cup water. Cover and cook for 20 to 25 minutes on medium flame till the chicken is done (mix occasionally to avoid burning). It should have some gravy 
- Leave the chicken on low flame for 5 minutes till the oil separates 
- Add the green chillies, coriander, black pepper & adjust salt 
- Serve hot with phulka, paratha or rumali roti

Upside Down Cheesecake Recipe ⤵️

Blueberry Compote 🫐
250 g frozen blueberries (or any fruit of your liking)
1/4 cup sugar 
1 tbsp lemon zest
1 tbsp lemon juice
1 tbsp cornflour dissolved in water 

- in a pan add the blueberries, sugar, lemon zest and juice. Cook till the berries have softened 
- Roughly mash the berries. Then thicken with a cornflour slurry (it should still be loose and not very thick)
- Set aside in the refrigerator to cool

Cheesecake Base 🥮
300 g crushed digestive biscuits 
1 tbsp caster sugar 
90 g melted butter 

- Mix all the ingredients till well combined 
- Press firmly in a lined 7 inch spring form pan going all the way up the sides
- Use a glass to smooth the edges and base. Refrigerate till usage 

Filling 🍰
170 g cream cheese 
3/4 cup icing sugar 
1 tsp vanilla essence 
1 tbsp lemon zest
1 tsp lemon juice 
1.25 cups whipped cream (measured after whipping)

- Beat the cream cheese, sugar and vanilla till smooth
- Add the lemon zest and juice. Mix well 
- Add the whipped cream and beat till just combined (filling should not be very stiff)
- Add half the filling in the prepared pan and spread evenly
- Add the blueberry compote followed by the remaining filling 
- Smoothen the top evenly and refrigerate for 4 to 6 hours until set
- Flip the cake gently on a plate and remove from the pan
- Serve chilled

Mulligatawny Soup Recipe ⤵️

30 Minute Meals Episode 8 - Mulligatawny Soup 🍲 

Ingredients
2 tbsp butter
2 small apple diced 
1 green chilli
9 to 10 peppercorns 
1 small onion chopped
3 cloves garlic crushed
2 inch piece ginger 
1/2 carrot 
1 small tomato (no seeds)
1/4 cup chopped celery stalks 
1 small potato peeled and cubed 
4 to 5 coriander stems
1/3 cup masoor daal (soaked for 30 min)
2.25 cups chicken or vegetable broth 
Few curry leaves 
1 cup water 
1 tsp curry powder (or 1 tsp garam masala + 1/3 tsp turmeric)
1 tsp salt
1/2 tsp turmeric 
1/2 cup coconut milk
Boiled rice & shredded chicken for serving 

- In a pan melt the butter. Add the apple, chilli, peppercorn, onion, ginger garlic, carrot, tomato, celery, potato & coriander stems 
- Sauté till the veggies are softened 
- Add the soaked daal, stock and curry leaves
- Cover and cook on medium flame for 15 to 20 minutes till everything is tender (alternatively pressure cook for 10 minutes)
- Blend the daal & then strain it (optional)
- Now add in the water, spices and bring to a boil. Taste & adjust the salt. Add more water if needed to get a creamy consistency 
- Temper the coconut milk to avoid curdling then add in the soup 
- Serve hot with boiled rice, shredded chicken & lemon wedges

PappaRoti Coffee Buns Recipe ⤵️

Bread Dough (6 small or 4 large buns)
200g flour
100ml Warm milk
28g beaten egg (about half an egg)
25 g caster Sugar
1/2 tsp Salt
1 tbsp Instant yeast
25 g room temperature unsalted butter 

- Combine the milk, sugar, egg & yeast in a bowl. Mix well
- Sift in the flour and salt. Knead a dough with soft hands 
- Add in the butter & knead in the dough (it may take 10 to 15 minutes for the butter to be completely incorporated)
- The dough should be soft and smooth 
- Spray with oil and cover with cling wrap
- Let it rise in a warm dark place for 60 to 90 minutes. Or until doubled in volume 

Filling
30 g unsalted butter 

- Cut the butter in 5g chunks and freeze until required 

Topping
35 g unsalted butter
35 g caster Sugar
1 pinch salt
28g beaten egg (about half an egg)
40 g flour
1/2 tbsp Instant coffee
1 tbsp Warm water

- Dissolve the coffee in the water
- In a separate bowl beat the butter and sugar
- Add the egg, coffee mixture and mix well (mixture might split)
- Add the flour and mix well till smooth
- Transfer to a piping bag and refrigerate till usage

Cold Cocoa Recipe ⤵️

Summer Quenchers: Italian Cold Cocoa 🍫🧊

Cold Cocoa Pre-Mix
1/2 cup sugar
1/2 cup sifted cocoa powder
1/2 cup cornflour
1/8 tsp salt
1/2 tsp cinnamon powder (optional)

- Mix all the ingredients and store in a clean, dry jar on the counter for 4 months. Or in the freezer for up to 1 year

Cold Cocoa 
1 cup milk (245 ml)
2 tbsp finely chopped dark chocolate (I used 70%)
2.5 to 3 tbsp hot chocolate pre mix
Ice for serving 

- in a pot add the premix along with a little bit of milk. Whisk till smooth & well combined
- Add the remaining milk and whisk together. Add in the chopped chocolate 
- Cook on medium heat till smooth, thick and velvety. Remove from heat 
- Keep whisking & cool down till room temperature. You can also cool until completely chilled in the fridge
- Add lots of ice in a glass, pour the cold cocoa and top with whipped cream/shaved chocolate 
- Serve chilled

Nizami Dum ka Murgh Recipe ⤵️

Hyderabadi Food Series Episode 15: Nizami Dum ka Murgh 🍗

Ingredients (Serves 4)

Shahi Masala Paste 🥥
10 almonds
10 cashew nuts 
1/2 cinnamon stick
1 star anise
2 cardamom 
3 cloves 
3 tbsp desiccated coconut 
5 garlic cloves
2 inch ginger 
1 green chilli

- Dry roast the whole spices, almonds, cashews and coconut till golden & fragrant 
- Add the ginger, garlic and green chilli
- Blend in a smooth paste with some water 

Chicken Marination 🥘
750 g chicken with bone
150 g yogurt 
1 tsp shahzeera
1/2 tsp turmeric
1.5 tbsp Kashmiri red chilli pwd 
3/4 tsp coriander pwd
1 tsp salt
3/4 tsp black pepper pwd 
1/2 tsp cardamom pwd 
1/2 tsp garam masala pwd
1 cinnamon stick, 2 cardamom, 3 cloves, 3 peppercorns 
2 large onions golden fried, crushed 
1/4 cup onion oil 
Handful coriander & mint leaves
2 green chillies chopped 
2 tbsp lemon juice 
2.5 tbsp desi ghee
Few strands saffron soaked in 1/4 cup warm milk
Charcoal piece 

- Marinade the chicken with all the listed ingredients & the prepared masala paste for at least 1 hour or preferably overnight 
- Transfer to a pot and put on high flame for 5 minutes till the chicken comes to a boil
- Now reduce the flame and cook on low for 35 to 45 minutes (keep stirring every 7 to 10 minutes to avoid masala from burning)
- The oil will separate. Adjust the salt. 
- Give a charcoal smoke for 5 to 10 minutes
- Mix and serve hot with rumali roti, phulka or naan

Garlic Chilli Oil Recipe ⤵️

30 Minute Meals Episode 7 - Chilli Peanut Noodles 🍜 

Garlic Chilli Oil 🌶️
1/4 cup chilli flakes
2 tbsp freshly crushed garlic
2 tbsp freshly crushed ginger 
2 tbsp chopped green onions (green part)
1/8 cup sesame seeds
1 tsp salt
1 tsp sugar
1 tsp Kashmiri Red Chilli Powder

3/4 cup neutral oil
Few coriander seeds, whole cardamom, peppercorns and 1 star anise 
1 bay leaf
Handful green onion bulbs (white part)

* Heat the oil in a pot with the whole spices, bay leaf and green onion bulbs
* Let it infuse for 5 to 10 min on medium heat
* Mix all the remaining ingredients in a jar
* Strain over the hot oil and let it sizzle
* Mix well and seal the lid. Let it cool completely 
* Store at room temperature 

Creamy Chilli Peanut Noodles 🥜
1 to 2 tbsp homemade chilli oil (depends on spice preference)
1 tbsp soy sauce
1/2 tbsp vinegar 
1/2 tsp sugar 
2 tbsp peanut butter
2 tbsp noodle water 
1 cup boiled noodles (I used egg noodles)

- Mix the chilli oil with all the sauces & water 
- Toss in the hot boiled noodles 
- Garnish with more chilli oil & green onions
- Serve immediately

Hyderabadi Dalcha Recipe ⤵️

Hyderabadi Food Series Ep 14: Kaddu ka Dalcha 🍛

Ingredients (Serves 5 to 6)
130 g Chana daal
20 g masoor daal
2 cloves garlic 
1 tsp turmeric 
Water as required 

- Wash & soak the daals for 1 hour
- Transfer to a pressure cooker with the remaining ingredients 
- Cook for 20 to 25 minutes till fully tender
- Mash or blend the daal till smooth & set aside 

1/2 cup oil
1 tsp shahzeera
4 cardamom 
5 cloves
3 small pieces cinnamon
3 bayleaf 
1 large onion sliced 
2 tbsp ginger garlic paste 
1 tbsp Kashmiri red chilli pwd 
1 tsp turmeric
1 tsp salt
1 tsp coriander pwd 
2 large tomatoes peeled & chopped 
500 g mutton with bone
1 medium bottle gourd (peeled & seeds removed)
 Handful tamarind soaked in warm water 
10 - 12 curry leaves 
4 green chillies slit
Handful chopped coriander 
salt as required 
3/4 tsp garam masala pwd

- In a pan heat the oil & fry the whole spices 
- Add the onion & fry till golden
- Add the ginger garlic paste, dry spices and tomatoes. Cook till the tomatoes are tender
- Add the mutton and fry for 2 minutes 
- Now add 1 glass water and cook on low heat till the mutton is 80% cooked (can also pressure cook)
- Add the bottle gourd and tamarind water. Mix & bring to a boil. Now remove the bayleaves and cinnamon sticks 
- Add the boiled daal with 2 cups water 
- Add all the remaining ingredients and mix well
- Cover and cook on low heat for 10 to 20 minutes till the gourd is tender and the oil separates 
- Serve hot with Bagara rice

Kheer Puri – A Taste of Tradition, A Memory of Togetherness

For Hyderabadis, Kheer Puri is not an everyday sweet, it’s a tradition reserved for the blessed occasion of Milad-un-Nabi ﷺ.
On this day, homes would come alive with the aroma of kheer simmering and puris puffing, as families gathered around the dastarkhwaan to celebrate with love and togetherness.

Amtul Faheem from @ammi.ke.khane recalls a cherished memory, her sister once stubbornly demanded Kheer Puri from their mother. But by the time it was prepared, she had already fallen asleep, leaving behind a story the family still laughs about.

Back then, children in every home eagerly waited for this special treat, calling out, “Ammi, Kheer Puri banao!”
Today, many bakeries have started selling Kheer Puri, and while the taste may be there, the joy of making it at home, the togetherness, and the love in every bite are missing.

That’s why she says, make Kheer Puri at home. Because some dishes are not just about flavor, they’re about faith, family, and timeless memories.

✨ Special Dish: Hyderabadi Kheer Puri, best enjoyed on Milad-un-Nabi with loved ones.

Follow their journey on Instagram & YouTube:
@ammi.ke.khane

Recipe ⬇️

(600 Cals, 40g P - For the Full Recipe - Divide into 2)

Ingredients:

5 tbsp Besan
1 Cup (200g) Greek Yogurt/ Amul High Protein Curd 
Spices - Salt, 1 tsp red chilli powder, 1 tsp haldi
7-8 Cups of water (if you are using greek yogurt, you may need more water)

1 tsp ghee
6-7 curry leaves
1 tsp mustard seeds
1/2 tsp methi seeds
2-3 peppercorns
Pinch of hing
1 tsp jeera
2 dried red chillies
2 green chillies
1 medium thinly sliced onion
25g Soya Chunks (boiled and squeezed well)
1 Cup Chopped Spinach
1 tbsp Ginger Garlic Paste
1/2 tbsp jaggery powder
Handful coriander

1. Make a smooth mixture of curd, besan and spices mentioned above. Add water and mix again until there are no lumps. The consistency should be watery
2. In a pan, add ghee and then add curry leaves, mustard, hing, peppercorns, dried red chillies, green chillies, methi seeds and jeera
3. Sauté for 2 mins and add onion. Cook for 3-4 mins and then add spinach along with boiled soya chunks
4. Saute for 3-4 minutes and add the besan mixture. 
5. Cover and cook for 4-5 mins and add the ginger garlic paste along with jaggery powder. (You may add water if it seems too thick)
6. Cover and cook again for 15 mins on low flame until the curry thickens a little. 
7. Garnish with coriander and serve with steaming hot basmati rice!

Recipes ⬇️

Btw, I have 25 more chia pudding recipes to share!!! Coming up soon❤️

✅Start with one simple base:
Mix 6 tbsp chia seeds + 3 scoops Oziva’s Vanilla Plant Protein + 150 ml watwr + 600 ml milk. Stir and let it thicken for 5-6 hours in the fridge.

Now for the fun part, first divide the chia pudding base in 3 parts👇

🍌1. Banoffee Chia Pudding - 500 Cals
Layer chia base → 1 caramelized banana (cooked for 5 mins with cinnamon powder and some butter on a pan) → few toasted walnuts → another layer of chia pudding→ top with more banana, crushed walnuts & 1 tsp nut butter.

☕️ 2. Mocha Chia Pudding - 480 Cals
Mix the chia base with 1 tbsp cocoa powder. Whisk 100g Greek yogurt with 1 espresso shot & sweetener of choice.
Layer chocolate chia pudding → coffee yogurt → repeat → top with dark chocolate nibs & chopped cashew.

🍓 3. Peanut Butter & Jelly - 510 Cals
Cook a few blueberries on low flame with 2–3 tbsp water for 4–5 mins until jammy, add lemon zest. Layer chia base → blueberry compote → 1 tsp peanut butter → repeat → finish sunflower and pumpkin seeds.

💚 Each jar gives ~35g protein! Store in the fridge for 3 days in airtight containers and repeat the process on wednesday night🥰

Recipe⬇️

Without sauce - 345 Cals, 15g P
With the Sauce - 420 Cals, 18g P

✅ Ingredients ⬇️
For the tofu marinade:
120g tofu 
1 tsp chili oil
1 tsp brown sugar
1 tbsp soy sauce
Pinch of Pepper
1 tsp vinegar
Salt & chili flakes to taste
1 tsp oil (for cooking)

For the rolls:
3 rice paper sheets
½ carrot, cut into thin sticks
1 medium cucumber, cut into thin sticks
A few lettuce leaves

For the dipping sauce:
3/4th tbsp peanut butter
½ tbsp chili sauce
Juice of ½ lemon
2 tbsp water
A pinch of salt

✅ Recipe ⬇️
🌶 In a bowl, mix chili oil, brown sugar, soy sauce, salt, and chili powder. Add tofu sticks and marinate for 10–15 mins.
🌶 Heat 1 tsp oil in a pan and cook tofu until golden brown on all sides.
🌶 Prepare the sauce by mixing peanut butter, chili sauce, lemon juice, water and salt until smooth.
🌶 Soak one rice paper sheet in water for 5–10 seconds until soft.
🌶 Place tofu, carrot, cucumber, and lettuce on it, then roll it up like a burrito.
🌶 Repeat for the remaining sheets.
🌶 Cut into halves and serve the rolls with the spicy peanut chili lime dip.

Final Ep - High Protein Sitaphal Custard!!

Makes 6-7 bowls (190-220 Cals per bowl, 7-8g Protein)

✅ Ingredients –
1.5 cups Makhana 
10–12 Cashews 
3 tbsp Melon Seeds
500 ml Country Delight High Protein Milk
Kesar strands soaked in 2 tbsp milk
1.5 medium Sitaphal (Custard Apple) pulp 
1.5–2 tbsp 0-calorie sweetener (Stevia/Monk Fruit)
½ Apple (chopped)
7–8 Grapes (halved)
½ Pomegranate (seeds)
1 Chiku (sliced)
1/2 Banana (sliced)
2 tbsp Chopped Nuts (for garnish)

✅ Method –
🌸 Lightly heat the high-protein milk — don’t boil it, just warm enough.
🌸 Add makhana, cashews, and melon seeds, kesar milk to the high protein milk and let them soak for a couple of hours until soft.
🌸 Once soaked, blend everything together into a smooth, creamy custard base.
🌸 Add the Sitaphal pulp and mix well.
🌸 Stir in 1.5–2 tbsp 0-calorie sweetener (adjust to taste).
🌸 Fold in all the chopped fruits and garnish with chopped nuts.
🌸 Serve chilled and enjoy🥰

Makes 10 pieces - 4 vertical cuts and 1 horizontal cut - 97 Cals per piece with 5.4g Protein (For video purpose, I have cut only into 5 slices)
✅Ingredients -
Half litre toned milk 
100g low fat homemade paneer crumbled
1 tsp elaichi powder
6-7 Dates soled in water and blended into Paste (This is majorly for color, if you want it more sweet, I recommend adding stevia/monkfruit sweetner for keeping it lower in cals)
Half scoop unflavored protein powder (optional a can replace with 2 tbsp milk powder)
Chopped pista for garnish
1/2 Tbsp ghee

🌸Boil milk in a non stick kadhai and let it simmer until it reduces to half. Keep mixing every 3-4 mins or it will stick
🌸Add paneer, elachi powder, protein powder and dates paste. 
🌸Mix well and keep cooking for 5-6 mins on low flame and stir in between
🌸Add ghee and mix again. Cook for another 5 mins until you see the mixture leaving sides of the kadhai and becoming brownish
🌸Set in a greased mould and garnish with pista (optional step)
🌸Refrigerate for 30 mins and its ready!! Cut into 10 pieces and enjoy❤️

Ep 3 - Low Calorie Karanjis
Recipe ⬇️ (98 cals per piece)

Ingredients
	•	Rice paper – 8-9 sheets
	•	Low Fat Paneer – 3/4th cup (crumbled)
	•	Fresh grated coconut – 1 cup
	•	Dried Anjeer – 9–10 (chopped)
	•	Sooji – 1.5 tbsp
	•	Handful Almonds, Raisins and Cashews
	•	Ghee – 1.5 tsp (for roasting)
	•	Elaichi powder – ¼ tsp
	•	Water – to soften rice paper

1️⃣ Roast sooji till golden and keep aside.
2️⃣ Dry-roast nuts till slightly brown.
3️⃣ In a little ghee, roast coconut till fragrant & light brown.
4️⃣ Add paneer + anjeer + elaichi → sauté 2–3 mins.
5️⃣ Grind everything (except sooji) into a smooth mix.
6️⃣Mix in the sooji and the filling is ready.
Dip rice paper in water for a few seconds → place 2 tbsp filling → fold into triangular shapes
7️⃣Brush lightly with ghee & air-fry at 180°C for 5 mins, flipping once till golden & crisp.
🌸 Enjoy immediately, or it will get soggy later!!

Ep 2 - Mini Pyaaz Kachori - Recipe ⬇️

Makes 14 kachoris - (78 Cals per Kachori, 3g P) 

✅Dough - 
1 Cup Khapli aata from @twobrothersorganicfarmsindia 
1/4th cup Suji
2 tbsp besan
1 1/2 tbsp Ghee 
Pinch of Ajwain
Salt to taste
1/4th cup Water (or a little more if needed)

🌸Mix everything together and make sure to rub ghee into the flour first until you get a crumbly feel. 
🌸Then add water spoon-by-spoon and rest the dough for 25 min covered.

✅Filling -
1.5 Onions
2 tsp ghee
25g Soya Chunks (weigh raw)
1 tsp saunf
Salt to taste
1 tsp jeera
4-5 garlic cloves + 2-3 green chillies crushed
1/2 tsp red chilli powder
1/2 tsp aamchur powder
Pinch of haldi

🌸In a pan, add ghee, saunf and jeera
🌸Then sauté garlic and chilli paste for 1-2 mins
🌸Add onions and let it cook on medium flame until brown and caramalized.
🌸Add soya chunks (boiled, squeezed and ground into granules) to this
🌸Add all masalas and let this cook for 6-7 mins 
🌸Now roll a big roti from the dough and using a katotri take out little circles
🌸Fill in the masala and tightly seal the kachoris
🌸 Preheat paniyaram pan for 2 min on low-medium flame
🌸Add ½ tsp ghee per cavity.
🌸Place kachoris in the cavity and brush with some ghee on top
🌸Cook 6–7 min, flip, cover again 6–7 min.
🌸Uncover + crisp each side 1-2 min on medium.

Recipe ⬇️ (690 Cals and 35g Protein for the whole thing, divide into 2-3 portions)

✅Ingredients for base -
3-4 Cashews
3-4 Almonds
2-3 Tbsp Oats
2 Tsp Ghee
2 Dried Anjeer
Pinch of Elaichi Powder
Pinch of Nutmeg Powder

🌸Roast the oats and nuts for 4-5 mins
🌸Grind everything together and spread the base in your container. Press it down firmly using a spatula and let it sit in the fridge for 10 mins

✅For the cream layer -
100g low fat paneer (preferably homemade)
80g greek yogurt
1/2 tbsp gulkand
3-4 Betal Leaves
1 tsp Saunf
Sweetner of choice (I used monkfruit which is zero calories, you can subsitute with honey)
2-3 tbsp pistachios soaked in hot water
Pinch of elaichi powder

🌸Blend everything together until silky smooth. You may add little yogurt if mixture seems too thick
🌸Pour this over your base layer. Garnish with chopped pista and dried rose petals
🌸Set in the fridge for 4-5 hours and its ready!!

4-5 Tbsps Peanut butter
Pinch of salt

This is How I manage my time for everything ✅
.
Welcome to Day-1 of Transforming My Dad🤝
.
Waking up at 4 a.m. every day allows me to take full control of my time and set the tone for a productive day. As an online fitness coach, my mornings are sacred. I use the quiet hours to focus on myself before I start serving others. This early start gives me time to plan my clients’ programs, respond to messages, and prepare for online sessions without distractions. It’s not just about waking up early, but about being intentional with every hour prioritizing my energy, discipline, and mindset so I can show up as my best self for my clients 🙌🏻

Time management is the foundation of success, both in fitness and in life. When you learn to manage your time, you create structure, consistency, and balance all of which are essential for achieving long-term goals. Without a plan, it’s easy to feel overwhelmed and lose focus. But when you take charge of your schedule, you take charge of your results. Whether it’s sticking to your workouts, eating right, or running a business, mastering your time helps you stay consistent, reduce stress, and make steady progress toward your goals ✅
.

Do not miss the end part‼️

Trying Bombay street food and sushi for the first time was such a wild mix of flavors and experiences for me. The Bombay street food instantly hit me with its bold spices, strong aromas, and the chaotic energy that comes with every bite. I loved how every dish had its own surprise - something crispy, something tangy, and something that made my mouth tingle with spice. It felt like a full-on flavor explosion, and even though it was messy and intense, there was something really fun and comforting about it 🥰
.
Sushi, on the other hand, was the complete opposite - calm, clean, and elegant. I remember being surprised by how simple it looked but how balanced the flavors were: the freshness of the fish, the slight sweetness of the rice, and that little kick from the wasabi. It felt more about appreciating each bite slowly rather than being overwhelmed by flavors. Experiencing both cuisines made me realize how food can tell such different stories,one full of color and chaos, the other quiet and refined and I honestly loved both in their own way 🙌🏻
.

I tried sushi for the first time today, and it was such a unique experience. At first, I wasn’t sure what to expect but the presentation looked so elegant and delicate, with the rolls neatly arranged and a burst of color from the fish, rice, and vegetables. The first bite completely changed my perspective on raw fish; it was surprisingly fresh, soft, and flavorful. The combination of textures ,the smooth fish, and a hint of wasabi and soy sauce,created a balance that felt both light and satisfying 🙌🏻
.
What stood out the most was how clean and refreshing it tasted compared to most other dishes I’ve tried. Each piece felt like a small, well-crafted work of art, and I could really appreciate the simplicity and precision behind it. It was more than just a meal,it was an experience of flavor and culture. Now that I’ve tried it, I understand why sushi is so popular, and I’m definitely excited to explore more varieties next time 🙌🏻
.

You won’t believe what happened ‼️
.
Fulfilling a childhood dream hits differently..
it’s more than just ticking something off a list; it’s an emotional reminder of how far you’ve come. Ever since I watched the movie Orange, Bombay had a special place in my heart: the vibe, the energy, the stories hidden in every corner of the city. Today, standing here and seeing it all in real life feels surreal. It’s like that little version of me, who once dreamed about this moment, is smiling somewhere inside. Every sight, sound, and feeling reminds me why dreams are worth holding onto ❤️

To everyone reading this, never give up on your dreams, no matter how small or far away they seem. Life has a beautiful way of rewarding those who stay patient and persistent. The journey might take time, but when you finally reach that destination, every struggle and wait makes sense. Keep believing, keep pushing because one day, you’ll be standing in the middle of your dream, just like I am today 🙌🏻
.

You’ll be shocked to know this‼️
.
When I was a child, I used to watch my friends excitedly talk about their flight trips,the clouds they saw, the snacks they got, and the joy of flying. I’d run home and ask my mom why we couldn’t do the same, and she would smile softly and say, “Maybe one day, when we can afford it.” At the time, I didn’t fully understand what that meant, I just knew my mom worked hard to give me everything she could, even when life gave her so little 🥹

Today, I hold a flight ticket in my own hands,one I bought with my own money. It’s proof that I made it somewhere she always dreamed I would reach. But as I stand here, I can’t help but feel a deep ache in my heart. Because this moment, the one she always wanted for me, feels incomplete without her by my side. I wish she could see how far her love and sacrifices have taken me, I wish she were here to fly with me, just once..❤️
.

You will be shocked to see this😱
.
After 20 years of avoiding papaya, I finally decided to give it another shot mostly out of curiosity. Growing up, I couldn’t stand the smell or the texture, and it was one of those fruits I swore I’d never touch again. But something about seeing it freshly cut this time made me think, “Why not?” So, I took a bite, fully expecting to regret it immediately ‼️

To my surprise, it wasn’t bad at all in fact, it was actually good. The sweetness, the smooth texture, and that refreshing aftertaste completely changed my mind. Maybe my taste buds just needed two decades to evolve, or maybe papaya wasn’t the problem… I was. Either way, I’m officially team papaya now proof that sometimes, you’ve got to give old dislikes a second chance ✅
.

Comment “mom” and I will send u all the details of my mom-friendly workout series which can be followed at home using just mat and dumbbells 💪 
Why these exercises are mistakes ? Here’s the explanation :
✅ Planks are fine before babies but after delivery women’s tummy goes through a condition called Diastasis Recti and planks worsen the gap between the 6 pack ab muscles making the tummy look protruding even more like you are still pregnant. Side plank is the perfectly safe alternative. 
✅ Crunches again should be avoided if you are postpartum mom as it worsens the DR, hip bridge marching is the perfectly safe alternative for this. 
✅ Excess everyday cardio and zero strength training can ruin your fat loss progress as it won’t contribute in building muscle, so 1 day cardio and 4 days strength training is perfect combo for fat loss + strength building. 
✅ Light and  colourful dumbbells are ok for few weeks if u are a complete beginner, but gradually increasing the weight of dumbbells can help with better progress and breaking plateaus. 
✅ Flexibility traning is great but without mobility training there are lot of chances of injuries so more focus should be done on mobility speacially when u start your fitness journey after a long gap.

These busy moms are proof that a realistic approach works, even with family schedules, pizza nights, and crazy mornings.

If you’re ready to finally feel in control of your fitness again…

Drop a 🔥 below!!!

I used to go to bed every night feeling guilty.

Guilty for eating too much, for not being perfect. And most mornings, I’d wake up already feeling defeated. I’d failed before the day even started.

I spent years stuck in that cycle, eating as little as possible then bingeing when I couldn’t take it anymore and promising myself I’d “start over Monday.”

Going too low didn’t make me disciplined. It made me miserable. I was exhausted, burnt out, and constantly thinking about food.
 
And that’s when I learned what worked in my teens sure as hell didn’t work in my 30s.

The moment I started fueling my body instead of punishing it, everything changed my energy, my mindset, my results.

If you’re stuck in that same cycle, I get it.
You don’t need another diet. You need a plan that actually fits your life.

✨ Message us READY and we’ll help you build something sustainable, for good.

Choose YOUR hard….
Staying stuck or doing the work 💪🏼🤍

You don’t need to change everything.
You just need to stay consistent with something.

Small wins build confidence.
Confidence builds consistency.
Consistency changes everything.

At some point, you have to stop waiting for the perfect time and decide you’re done feeling stuck.

You deserve to feel confident walking into a room again, to have energy, patience, and pride in the woman looking back at you in the mirror.

✨ Comment READY for more info on 1:1 coaching.

Everyone told me my 20s would be the best years of my life.

They weren’t.

I became a mom at 19, while everyone else was out finding themselves, I was trying to raise a tiny human and hold myself together. Working full time to support my husband through school, Sleep deprived, Stressed, Living off caffeine and whatever I could grab that was easy.

My skin broke out WORSE than in highschool, my gut was wrecked and my body constantly felt inflamed.
I lost myself.

I had 2 more kiddos and I thought that was just how motherhood had to feel, tired, puffy, anxious and stretched thin.

But it wasn’t.

I had to learn the hard way that you can’t pour from an empty cup.
That healing your gut, fueling your body, and finding peace again isn’t selfish. 

Now, as a mom of three, my 30s look completely different.

Real energy, confidence in my skin, strength that comes from taking care of myself, not punishing myself.

If you’re in that messy middle, exhausted, inflamed, and wondering where you went I promise she’s still in there.

She’s just waiting for you to take care of her again. 

Comment CHANGE below and I’ll send you our Busy Mama Guide it’s everything I wish I had when I was trying to find my way back.🤍

Most women don’t realize weekends make up 30% of their week.

If you treat them like a free for all, you’ll spend your whole life trying to “get back on track.

Start practicing your habits through the weekend too…even just one anchor habit that keeps you grounded:

Hitting your water goal
Getting a protein based breakfast
Going for a walk before the day gets busy
Tracking one meal
Going to bed on time

You don’t need to be perfect on weekends, you just need to stay connected to one thing that keeps you feeling aligned.

Which anchor habit do you stay consistent with over the weeekend?

If fall has you short on time, grab anything with weight and get it done.

Equipment: A pumpkin (or dumbbell)
Format: 30 seconds per exercise
Rest: 30 seconds after the round
Rounds: 3 total 

Exercises:
Squat
Dumbbell (or pumpkin) swings
Row
Tricep extension
Shoulder press
Rest

For years I thought being healthy meant eating less and doing more.

Now I know it means showing up with enough energy to chase my kids, lift heavy, and actually enjoy my life.

If you’ve spent years chasing quick fixes only to end up tired, cold, and burnt out. I’ve been there, and it sucks. 

I promise you there is a better way No crash diets. No more starting Monday. Just strength, food that fuels you, and a plan that fits your busy mom life. 

DM us “READY” and we will help you build a plan that lasts. 💪🏻

You don’t need more motivation.
You need to stop negotiating with yourself.

Every time you say “I’ll start tomorrow,” you teach your brain that your word doesn’t matter.
 Discipline isn’t built in big moments, it’s built every time you follow through when it’s inconvenient.

🤍Save this for the days you start talking yourself out of showing up.

Not a total life overhaul, but the kickstart you’ve been waiting for 👏🏻👏🏻 

You don’t need hours in the gym or extreme diets just consistency, movement, and a plan that actually fits your life.

Our next challenge starts November 3rd, and it’s designed to help you:
💧 Build momentum with simple daily habits
🏋️‍♀️ Feel stronger with 20–30 min home workouts
🥗 Get back on track with balanced, realistic nutrition
👏🏻 Feel supported every step of the way

This isn’t about being perfect, it’s about finally proving to yourself that you can do this.

Comment 👏🏻 to get started,  let’s make these next 4 weeks the push that changes your direction 🔥

We hear “I’m eating 1200 calories and not losing weight” all the time….But here’s the truth 👇🏼
 If your weight isn’t dropping, your average intake is higher than you think.

Your body doesn’t magically stop burning fat. It adjusts to your habits, your movement, your consistency… or lack of it.

So before blaming your metabolism, get honest about:
 ✅ Tracking everything … bites, oils, weekends ✅ Staying consistent longer than 5 days ✅ Moving more than just during workouts

Fuel your body right. Be consistent. Then watch what happens. 🤍
The safest option is just to work out at home😅

You’re just waiting for life to get easier…
But what if it doesn’t?

What if January rolls around and you’re still overwhelmed, exhausted, stretched thin..
Except now you’re starting from scratch, again.

The ones who actually see results, they don’t wait. They start when it’s hard, When it feels chaotic, when it’s the last time they feel like adding one more thing.

✨✨If you’re done with the all-or-nothing cycle DM us “START” and I’ll show you how we build this differently.

But I have good news..👇🏻

That comfort zone isn’t permanent. Once you reach your new weight and maintain it, your body adjusts.

That will become your new set point.

When you stay consistent with weight lifting, eating enough protein, sleeping, your body learns this new version of you is here to stay👏🏻👏🏻👏🏻✨

Follow for more real talk about how to build a body that actually feels good to live in. 🤩

Even 20 minutes in your living room can flip your entire day.

You don’t need motivation, you just need to start.

Who is getting a workout in today?! 🙌🏻

I fully admit, I was in denial. 😅
I didn’t really feel like my body had changed that much.

But one day, my sister looked at me and said, “Get on the scale.” I laughed it off, but I did it, and I was 155. That’s when I realized I had weight blindness.

The scale had slowly crept up over time. A few pounds here, a few there. And because I wasn’t paying close attention, I didn’t notice just how far off track I had gotten.

Here’s the thing, it’s 100% okay to be whatever weight if you feel good, strong, and healthy. But I wasn’t. I was tired, bloated, uncomfortable in my skin, and deep down, I knew I wasn’t living in alignment with how I wanted to feel.

Sometimes we need people in our lives who will lovingly tell us the truth. Who won’t let us keep living in denial. Who will help us pull our heads out of the sand and face reality.

No one’s going to save you. Not a new outfit. Not a round of Botox. Not a Monday start date. Not another round of excuses.
You have to get honest with yourself and decide to take your power back.

#weightblindness #weightlossjourney #toughlove #gethonest #noonescomingsavetoyou #realtalk #fitnessmindset

Teach your child 👇🏻👇🏻

to get stronger, not smaller.
to eat without guilt.
to rest without shame.
to move because it feels good, not because they should.

The most powerful thing we can show our kiddos is peace with our own bodies.

If you can survive Bulgarian split squats, you can survive anything 💀

They hurt… but they also remind you how strong you are.
⠀
Busy days. Work. Kids. Life.

You show up, you push through, and you come out stronger every single time. 💪🏼

👇🏼 These are the signs your deficit is doing what it should

Your measurements or clothes are changing: Body fat loss happens before the scale always reflects it. Your jeans or sports bra fit tell the truth faster than the scale does.

You’re feeling more energized, not depleted: A proper deficit shouldn’t leave you exhausted or foggy. If your energy is stable throughout the day, that’s a good sign you’re fueling enough while still in a deficit.

You’re noticing small hunger cues You should feel slightly hungrier at times, that’s your metabolism working …but you shouldn’t feel starved or obsessed with food.

Your strength is improving or holding steady: If you’re maintaining or increasing strength in your lifts, it means you’re losing fat, not muscle …exactly what you want.

You’re consistent without perfection: You’re tracking most days, hitting protein, and staying within range & not giving up every weekend or starting over on Monday.

These are the real indicators your plan is working,not just the number on the scale. Fat loss is a process, and the women who see it through are the ones who focus on these signs, not just weight.

An Air India flight en route to London’s Gatwick Airport crashed just minutes after taking off from Ahmedabad, plunging into the Meghani Nagar residential area. The aircraft, identified as Flight AI171, was a Boeing 787 Dreamliner carrying 230 passengers and 12 crew members.

The flight took off from Runway 23 at 1:39 PM IST, and according to officials, it issued a MAYDAY call moments later.

Contact with Air Traffic Control (ATC) was lost soon after, and the aircraft reportedly crashed minutes after departure, just outside the airport perimeter.

The flight was being operated by Captain Sumeet Sabharwal, a senior pilot with over 8,200 flying hours, and First Officer Clive Kundar, who had logged 1,100 hours of experience.

Eyewitnesses reported heavy black smoke billowing from the crash site. Emergency response teams, including firefighters and police, immediately sealed off the area and began rescue operations.

Back pain at an early age can be caused by poor posture, especially from spending long hours sitting hunched over phones, computers, or school desks. Carrying heavy backpacks incorrectly, lack of regular exercise, or weak core muscles can also put extra strain on the spine. In some cases, injuries from sports or sudden movements contribute to discomfort.

Medical conditions can play a role too. Issues like scoliosis, herniated discs, or congenital spinal abnormalities may develop during childhood or adolescence. Additionally, being overweight or experiencing high stress levels can worsen back problems by increasing physical or muscular tension.

Babies are flexible because their bones are softer and made up of more cartilage than adult bones, allowing their bodies to bend and adapt easily. Their joints and ligaments are also looser, which helps them fit through the birth canal and move freely as they grow.

This flexibility plays a key role in their development, making it easier for them to learn to roll, crawl, and eventually walk. Over time, their bones harden and their joints stabilize, gradually reducing that natural bendiness as they get older.

Most adults need 7 to 9 hours of sleep per night to function at their best. This amount helps the body repair tissues, regulate hormones, and maintain a healthy immune system. While some people feel fine on slightly less, consistently sleeping under 6 hours can lead to fatigue, poor focus, and long-term health problems.

Quality matters as much as quantity. Deep and REM sleep are essential for memory, learning, and emotional balance. Irregular schedules, stress, and screens before bed can reduce sleep quality, even if the total time seems enough. A consistent bedtime routine and good sleep environment help adults get the full restorative benefits of sleep.
